There has been no indication at all of whether the development bank will still be able to make additional finance available to rural industry and small business. The Commonwealth Development Bank, operating Australia-wide—and particularly in Victoria where it operates in conjunction with Rural Finance Victoria—has been very important in providing finance to farmers to develop their industry and their farms. We do not know what the future of that bank is.

I am sure the government has not considered the future of the Commonwealth Development Bank. There is certainly nothing in the budget statement about the future of this bank. I am greatly concerned, not only about the access to finance but also about the employees of the development bank. It is quite obvious that if the Commonwealth Bank is sold the subsidy will not be available. What will happen to the employees? Will there be further reductions? As I indicated to you earlier, the bank has already reduced its staff from 55,000 to 35,000, and a lot of those people are former employees of the State Bank of Victoria. Are the employees of the Commonwealth Development Bank also at risk?

Regrettably, my time has run out, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think it is appalling that the government has made so little time available for members to comment on this very important bill when it is before the parliament during this session.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) and support his well chosen comments. I represent an electorate which is in the bottom 10 per cent of Australia by income. It gives me no pleasure to say that, but it is typical of a changing Australia which has forgotten where its real strength lies. My electorate is also one which has a higher percentage than the national average of people who are either self-employed or involved in a small business. So we have a high percentage of self-employed people and those people in small business, and we have some of the least well-off people in our community.

PARA.TAB: The fudge-it budget, as it has become known, simply ignores regional Australia. It has become a habit for this government, and in an urban dominant society it is not hard to understand why that has occurred. But the reality is that 80 per cent of our export wealth is generated in regional Australia. When we look at the budget figures, we see that $17 million is allocated to support regional development in regional Australia; yet $245 million is given to cities, to the urban centres of Australia. It is $17 million for regional development and $19 million for regional strategic infrastructure.

As for the program of $160 million over four years, that much quoted figure, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) was able to stretch it so far as to quadruple it the other day at a meeting at Port Augusta when he said it was $160 million per year over four years. I do not think the Treasurer (Mr Willis) knew about that and I guess the Treasurer ignored him anyway. But, given that the actual amount is $200,000 or $300,000 per electorate and that the extra taxation taken is millions of dollars per month out of each electorate, particularly regional electorates, we get a perspective of the imbalance that this government insists on inflicting not only on regional Australia but throughout Australia.

So what does the government offer us? It offers more punishment for those people who are employed, by taxing them more on their houses and on their cars, et cetera, and it offers more paperwork and more tax for small business. What does it offer those areas in regional Australia which have higher than the national average of unemployment? People would be familiar with the upper Spencer Gulf regions, Whyalla, Port Augusta and Port Pirie, and Port Lincoln at the bottom of the Eyre Peninsula, the bottom of Spencer Gulf. Those cities combined have high numbers of people on Department of Social Security benefit. So we have very little money spent, much more money spent in the cities, more tax on regional Australia and just that constant grind of the dole queue for those people living particularly in those regional cities.

It is rather ironic that today we had the One Nation train going into Adelaide, with joy abounding, no doubt, with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the controls and in control of all the levers, selling the benefits of his wonderful Labor team. That train will go on to Port Augusta minus the Prime Minister and will be in Port August at 4.30 this afternoon. At the same time the head of National Rail will be asked why there are going to be job losses in the hundreds in Port Augusta over the next few months as a result of the rationalisation of rail throughout Australia. Not only do we have job losses but we have this constant theme of a misunderstanding that people are looking for stable jobs, not just to rely on the welfare state.

The government has been claiming for some time that it had these long-term unemployment queues cured. It was pleasing although saddening to at least get the admission last week that those people were being recycled. Up to 50 per cent of those people were coming straight back out of their long-term unemployment category on to short-term unemployment. I have been searching for those figures for many months and at last we have the admission that those unemployment numbers are nowhere near as attractive as the government would have us believe.

I will talk briefly about the Commonwealth Bank. I have some emotional attachment to this topic because my first job was as a bank clerk in the humble old Bank of Adelaide, which had its demise some time ago. Having worked in that bank as a bank clerk at 15 years of age, I have always been a believer in a mixed economy. I had a strong belief that there was a strong role for private enterprise and for government. Oh, how that has suffered! Along with most South Australians, I suffered the indignity of seeing our State Bank absolutely wrecked. I accept that was not the direct responsibility of this government; the former Labor state government has to accept significant responsibility for that demise.

In this whole new deregulated financial system, I have seen many of the cornerstones of my beliefs in this society smashed to smithereens. So it is with the Commonwealth Bank. I guess, like billions of Australians, I had my little money box and, from time to time, in went those few pennies. The frugal amount accumulated into modest savings in that little blue book at the post office. Yet, that is sacrificed in the name of balancing the budget. The honourable member for Bendigo has spoken about the fact that the Labor caucus was not even consulted.

Let us look at that $4 billion; let us think about what the former Senator Peter Walsh recently said about asset sales. He regarded it as fraudulent to sell these assets to other people who simply use their savings to buy those assets from the government. All that has been done is to shift an asset from a government balance sheet to somebody else's balance sheet. It has done nothing to make the total amount of savings available throughout our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're transferring savings, too.

—Absolutely, as the honourable member says. There is considerable understanding of the accounting system and we know exactly what this national government is doing. So, we have the $4 billion there and we have the $4 billion l-a-w tax cuts that were not granted. Allegedly, three years down the track the money will be put into superannuation, or whatever. It really is quite a remarkable act of absolute effrontery to suggest that the government can have l-a-w tax cuts, sell the Commonwealth Bank and then claim that somehow or other, in that jumble, the money is going to be put into national savings three years down the track. It could just as easily be argued that we are going to have tax increases in three years time to pay for that $4 billion that we did not get this time or to pay for the $4 billion from the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. It is absolute folly to talk in these terms.

PARA.TAB: I conclude with a few comments about regional people and regional economy. I think it is too easy for us as a national parliament to give up on full employment. It is too easy for us to ignore regional Australia. I think most people concede this now. It is not just the political imperative of winning those half a dozen seats in central New South Wales. Regional Australia has been more severely damaged and suffers more severe disadvantage than urban Australia because of the policies of centralism and because of the indirect tax system. I think there is enough evidence—whether it is from EPAC, from Professor Gregory or whatever—to establish that many of the people living in regional Australia are amongst our poorest and most disadvantaged even though they provide 80 per cent of our exports.

I reiterate that, when the coalition is in government after the next election, we will get the balance between inflation, interest rates and growth correct in order to ensure that employment grows. We will get back to full employment levels—that is, something like three per cent. This has been ignored and neglected by this government. This has got to be our aim. It is an aim that this government has given up and that is the great tragedy of this fudge-it budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to the speaking list that we have today for this Appropriation Bill (No. 1). There are 26 opposition members but no government members. It goes to show that members of the government are too ashamed to come in here and try to defend the budget. It is indefensible. Also, our time to do this has been cut quite considerably. In the meantime, government members are not here, and they talk about lack of policies. I want to talk about the lack of truth and the political process around the 1993 elections. We were promised tax cuts. We were promised that there would be a permanent reduction in the sales tax on motor vehicles; that the Commonwealth Bank would not be sold and that the government would not have a lesser amount of equity in it than what it had at that stage; that the company rate of tax would be reduced; and, of course, that the Medicare levy would stay as it was.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at all of those promises in the light of what we are seeing today. The tax cuts have been forsaken and the company tax rate has increased, to the disadvantage of Australian companies trading against the Asian nations and against the New Zealand nation. We have been put at a severe disadvantage. The Commonwealth Bank—lo and behold!—is now for sale, unbeknown to the caucus and known only to the Treasurer (Mr Willis). What you see in the whole thing is a massive corruption of the political system. It is no wonder that people out there are wondering whether they can ever trust politicians again. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is a specialist in this corruption. People must be asking: who would trust him?

We in the opposition are accused of not having policies. I go on record as saying that never was a more comprehensive lot of policies placed before the people of Australia than at the last election. However, these have been corrupted for the sake of dishonesty and political advertising. I think Australia has lost a great opportunity. It has been hoodwinked. If I were going to the next election—I will not be—I would be saying that the only policy we want is to get rid of Keating and this corrupt government so that we can get on with the job of defending the Australian nation, defending the Australian character.

Let us look at the distortion that has come out of this budget as far as the deficit is concerned. I will start with the real deficit and how the government has fudged the issues to bring in what it has called an `implied surplus'. We start with a deficit of $8.23 billion. This is reduced by asset sales of $5.35 billion—selling off the public assets to reduce the deficit—$2.222 billion for repayment of the state debt, to which agreement my own state of Queensland was a willing partner, and the ABS adjustment of $1.378 billion. So we get the implied surplus of $718 million. What a hoodwink! It is no wonder that the people of Australia do not believe in politicians and parliaments. I believe that this has discredited us even further.

The budget, in its implication, was actually a spending spree, especially when we take into account the fact that the budget papers show an increase in taxation of 13.4 per cent. Yes, the Medicare levy went up; yes, the company tax rates went up; yes, the sales tax on motor vehicles went up; and, yes, a whole stack of other things went up. There has been a 13.4 per cent increase in total indirect and direct taxation and a spending spree which sees the government spending 5.3 per cent more than it did last year. Anybody who talks about restraint ought to have a look at those figures. Of course, this has all been done at the expense of selling off the family silver and the Australian assets.

I also pay particular attention to what has happened with the public debt interest bill. It has increased by some 23 per cent, from $8,134 million last year to $10,077 million this year. The payment of interest on the public debt accounts for 8.9 per cent of all the spending. If Australians appreciated how this country has been put into hock, they would quite determinedly shift this government next time.

`Small business will never have it so good again,' is one statement which has been made. We must consider small businesses and how they took that statement. I know the manner in which it has been taken in my electorate. I know the constraints under which small businesses have been operating in the last six months. I would say they have had some of the leanest years ever, and I think we will have to take those words as a threat, because perhaps the Prime Minister meant that it is not as good as people would want it to be but it is as good as it will get under Paul Keating as the Prime Minister.

In my own city, shops are closing and people for the first time are borrowing just to carry on. The impact of the fringe benefits tax is massive. The impact of that tax and the superannuation guarantee charge has meant that in my area there are now fewer people working in small business than before. There is just no encouragement. I was speaking to a farmer the other day who can grow 11,000 to 12,000 tonnes of cane and manage it himself. Provided he gets contract harvesting and planting done, he can look after 11,000 tonnes of cane. That is where the employment has gone; it is because of the impact of the fringe benefits tax and the superannuation guarantee charge now facing small business at four to five per cent, rising to nine per cent. As for the sales tax increases, the Prime Minister at the last election painted the GST as being a 15 per cent increase on everything. What is happening? We are getting those increases bit by bit through sales tax. That is the worst form of indirect taxation that business can suffer. No wonder they are going under at such a rapid rate of knots.

The foreign debt figure that I have, and it has probably increased since then, is $162 billion, yet the Prime Minister tries to explain that there are overseas deposits in reserve. Surely, when you talk about a net debt, that is net after the overseas reserves have been taken into consideration. This has risen from the 1983 figure of $23 billion to $162 billion now. When the Prime Minister talks about the overseas reserves, it is not only selling off the public assets such as Qantas and the bank to shore up his expenditure, but we are also seeing companies sold to overseas interests, including Arnotts biscuits; that parrot was as Australian as you could get. I understand that Nanna pies are now going overseas. The Australian meat pie is now going to be produced overseas and probably imported back into Australia so that we can have the typical Australian meat pie. Speedo, Edgell, ARC and all of those companies are the ones that are supplying the overseas reserves and the deposits because we are selling off not only the public assets but the private assets as well. I think this is something that should be considered.

Could I talk about housing? I know that throughout my electorate, and in other electorates in Queensland, there is a massive halt in the housing industry at the moment. Since Christmas there are people who have just put off their employees and are sitting down to wait. Why? Because they and the people who are buying houses have felt in the past the impact of high interest rates of this government and of the Prime Minister, and there is a great uncertainty about interest rates. There will continue to be an uncertainty about interest rates no matter how hard the Prime Minister tries to push them down, because the budget itself is not a real budget. It has implications of borrowing, it has implications that targets will not be met, and we will be in a worse situation, probably facing higher taxes in 12 months time than we are at the moment.

The trade deficit, estimated to come in at $27 billion, will have a massive impact not only on the foreign debt but on interest rates. Once the foreign exchange rate starts dropping a bit, there will be a decision made—probably not this side of an election but certainly the other side of the election—to push up interest rates to manage that. We have in addition a Prime Minister that no-one trusted in connection with interest rates when he was Treasurer, nor now as Prime Minister.

The sales tax additions, as I said before, are a de facto GST. This is just an outright grab for more taxes to cover the hole that could have been covered with a GST. I went looking for some details on the sales tax increases and I found no information available. They may be available by the end of June. The housing industry is going to have problems again.

I want to mention the drought in my area. We talk about the battlers of Australia. Primary industry people, particularly those in the bush who have suffered five years of drought, are not only battlers, they are also forgotten people. They have been forgotten by the government.

The rural adjustment scheme is a scandal. It does not apply itself to redressing the problems in the bush. The effects of this drought on the underground water supplies are being felt right along the Queensland coast.
The budget is a sham. The government is ashamed to bring its own members in here to speak to it. I believe the people of Australia ought to bear this in mind when they come to the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow my colleague the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I agree with a great deal of what he has said, particularly in regard to the small business sector. It is in that area that I would like to concentrate my comments this afternoon. Last week in my electorate the annual Logan City Chamber of Commerce small business awards were presented at a function which was attended by more than 500 local businessmen and women. It was a sell-out, as it usually is. It is one of the highlights of the Logan City business year. It pays tribute to and recognises the great contribution of local businesses to the economy of the city, to employment for the local community and, indeed, to the contribution that these organisations make to the nation. Export achievements are high on the recognition agenda.

PARA.TAB: The awards night is always attended by local political and community leaders, as it should be. After all, Logan City is Queensland's second or third biggest city. With more than 6,000 businesses registered there, it has one of the highest concentrations of small businesses in Australia.

Prior to the awards, the president of the chamber, Mr Kenneth Wong, gave his annual address, prefixing it with a statement that the chamber was non-political and did not play partisan politics. Mr Wong then launched into a tirade against the 1995-96 federal budget, especially the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) regarding the state of the economy and his gratuitous advice to small businessmen about going out and getting a job. Mr Wong expressed the frustration of his local small business community with the never-ending actions of the federal government penalising small business. His comments were met with resounding applause, much to the horror of the ALP state and federal parliamentarians presents.

The reality is that the government seems genuinely surprised that the 1995-96 budget has gone over like a lead balloon in the electorate. That surprise demonstrates just how out of touch the Prime Minister and his ministers are with mainstream Australia. In my electorate, which is very representative of mainstream Australia, this is a bad news budget. It is especially bad news for small business. Small business is increasingly the backbone of the Australian economy and of the economy of electorates such as mine. There is nothing in this budget for small business, that is, nothing positive or constructive. There is plenty in the budget which penalises small business and will make it even tougher for the small business sector to survive, let alone expand and create jobs for young Australians. Small business has rightly reacted with anger to the budget tax hikes which directly impact on small business.

What has been the Prime Minister's reaction to the concern and anger expressed by small business? With breathtaking arrogance he said, `This is as good as it's going to get for small business.' That statement will rank alongside the comment of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, when he said, `Silly old b' to a pensioner in Adelaide some years ago, both in terms of arrogance and insensitivity.

If one looks at the budget and a whole range of federal, state and local taxes and charges imposed on business, particularly on small business, it is little wonder that small business is doing it very tough. Yet the Prime Minister's only response is to say that things will not get any better and that small business ought to be grateful for what it got.

The worst affected area of small business as a result of the budget is the building industry. It has been one of the great bastions of small business and individual entrepreneurs in Australia for generations. Already hard hit by the impact of high interest rates, the building and housing industries have been dealt a cruel and, for many, a fatal blow in the budget.

For the first time, the budget introduces a sales tax on building materials, including materials used in home building. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) described the 12 per cent new tax as being `a concessional rate'. I can assure him that neither the building industry nor home buyers and people constructing buildings regard a 12 per cent tax as a concessional rate. This tax is a cruel and heartless body blow for the building and housing sectors, coming at a time when there is already a major downturn in housing construction and building activity, as the figures that were released last week confirm. By forcing up interest rates through bad fiscal and economic management, the government is proving that it could not care less about small business and about the housing and building sectors in particular.

The budget is even further proof of the willingness of this government to sacrifice small business so that it does not have to make the decisions that are tough on government rather than tough on business. Every small businessman or businesswoman needs one or more motor vehicles to conduct their business. Again, in this area, small business has been hardest hit of all, with the increase in the sales tax on motor vehicles—something that will cost the average car buyer about $1,000 per vehicle. We all would know in our electorates how flat the sales of new cars have been since about the end of January. This hike also hits motor dealers, many of whom are small businessmen operating in the suburbs, provincial towns and small towns. The downturn in housing and building will flow on to motor vehicle sales, if it does not do so already, because of the higher interest rates and the general slowing down in economic activity.

The government dealt yet another blow to small business with the three per cent income tax hike for company taxpayers. For a whole variety of legitimate reasons, many small businesses are structured as companies and pay company tax. For those still making a profit, this government has put its hand back into their pockets, and yet another 1993 federal election promise has been shamelessly broken. The small businessman paying tax on a PAYE basis will lose out, as well, with the second stage of the l-a-w tax cuts being abolished.

Is it any wonder that small business and even big business have reacted most negatively to the budget? Is it any wonder that mainstream Australia has given the budget the thumbs down, as well? The electorate has basically turned off the Prime Minister and the government, simply because they cannot be believed any longer. The electorate does not trust the government: it believes the government's promises are not worth a pinch of salt. Small business—which, as I said, is the backbone of the private sector—is turned off, first of all; and, increasingly, the whole electorate is doing so because of broken promises and bad government.

My particular electorate runs from the outskirts of Brisbane to the top of the Gold Coast. It encompasses the fastest growing part not only of Queensland but, indeed, of the whole nation. Small business is at the heart and soul of any electorate, serving population growth. I do not have dozens of large factories, but I do have hundreds and hundreds of small to medium-sized businesses, and many of them are doing it very tough indeed. Tragically, as a result of this budget, they will be joined by more, especially by those drawn from the building services, housing construction and retailing areas.

As long as the VIP jet is on stand-by, and as long as the French clocks and antiques are still selling well, the Prime Minister seems to be happy. I do not think that in this particular budget we have very much to be proud of at all. In actual fact, as the honourable member for Dawson mentioned, if it were not for asset sales, this budget would be an absolute disaster. It is indeed a smoke and mirrors trick. It is one that has been recognised by the Australian people as a fraud, and I basically believe that this government should be condemned by every Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and to also make the point, which some other members have made, that government members are not in here debating the budget. They are obviously not prepared today to defend the budget which the government has brought forward for the Australian people. That is an indication of the government's actual lack of confidence. Of course, that situation is underscored by the very fact that two or three of the main items were brought into the budget on the Sunday or Monday night prior to the budget, and government members did not even know anything about it.

PARA.TAB: Government members had no idea whatsoever, particularly in regard to the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank. The only reason that the government actually brought in the sale of the Commonwealth Bank was to try to get a positive effect out there. There was no other reason: there was no real logic to it, and no real consideration of what was good for Australia, or anything like that. It was just a matter of having a glossy effect. That decision underlies the way in which this budget has been put together.

I want to make some comparisons between when this government came into power and what it is like now. It is interesting that since 1983, over a period of about 12 years, the average weekly earnings of Australians have gone up by 90 per cent. But if you then have a look at the sort of management which this country has been under in regard to taxation, you will find this figure: individual taxation has increased by 136.8 per cent. So wages go up 90 per cent; individual taxation by 136.8 per cent. Is that what is helpful to the battler in Australia? Is that what is helpful to regional Australia? Is that what is helpful to working mums and dads who are trying to feed and clothe and provide educational facilities for their children? It certainly is not. Yet this government claims that this is a good budget. But we know that they are fudging figures, they are doing U-turns on promises, and least of all are they helping the ordinary, average Australian out there.

If you have a look at the company tax increase, the take is 370 per cent. Indirect tax is up 149.8 per cent. And listen to this one, the one that nobody really knows about, does not want to be involved with and that the government really canned in regard to the GST: sales tax in Australia is up 305.7 per cent. So this government is all the time spending big and the people who really pay for it and who are getting it in the back of the neck are the hard working, average income families in Australia. In 1983, average weekly earnings were $338 and last year the average was up to $642. As I said, average weekly earnings have gone up only by 90 per cent, but all of those taxation measures have gone up by more than 136 per cent in the same period of time.

When you have a look at, say, the state governments and how they are controlling their budgets, what you find is that in the last few years state budgets have been cut back and the states have cut their expenditure while the federal government is increasing its expenditure—and it is not just increasing, but increasing in real terms. Yet average Australians have gone through a time of belt tightening. And what do we find the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) doing in this budget? He says, `We can expand the Commonwealth's belt and we can off-load our expenditure onto ordinary Australians. They are the ones who can cop it. They can wear it.'

It is high time that this government was held to account and I say to the honourable member opposite, including the member for Calare (Mr Simmons), and the government that they ought to go to the people. Let the people have a say about this. The people are not happy with effectively having a new tax of 12 per cent on the family home. They are not happy with that, particularly after the government so heavily criticised, up hill and down dale, a goods and services tax. This really is a goods and services tax, for want of a better name; it is just that it is only on building supplies.

Then they want to increase the motor vehicle sales tax. We had a promise: to bring it down to 15 per cent. Of course, we all know there is a one per cent increase coming in about three weeks time, in July, quite apart from the five per cent. Yet this government promised tax cuts. Now they have done what is really a mirrors trick in regard to superannuation and tax cuts, holding out the benefit to Australian people by saying, `If you re-elect us, then the superannuation scheme and benefits which we are going to contribute to you in 1997-98, and which you will receive in the year 2025, are going to be of tremendous benefit. So save up for the nation. We are going to take it out of your pocket and we are going to give it back to you in 2025.' I say to the Australian people that in 1993 the Prime Minister promised tax cuts and by 1995 they were gone.

Does the government really expect the Australian people out there to believe that the Prime Minister can make a promise in 1995 about what is going to happen in regard to superannuation in 1998 and that that is going to be delivered in the year 2025? Of course not. Why should they? He has done a U-turn in regard to tax cuts and, as far as my electorate is concerned, he has done a U-turn in regard to the forest industries. We had an absolute debacle in that area in regard to the honesty of the Prime Minister and this government. They talk about having things done in a systematic, rational way in this country and say that everything is being scientifically decided in regard to the forest industries. So many small business people in Tasmania in my electorate are dependent on forest industries and the various businesses which grow up around those industries. Here we see small business in this budget being heavily attacked.

The forest industries are very important. I bring to the attention of people who are listening to this debate today that our overseas debt in the last quarter has gone up by $3.6 billion. That is over $200 per man, woman and child in the last three months. The government has the hide to tell us that the economy is going great, yet our debt overseas is going up! At the same time, in regard to the forest industries, one of the industries where we ought to be exporting product, we are actually importing $1.7 billion to $2 billion worth of product. It is just creating overseas debt. Why? Because this government procrastinates in regard to the second largest manufacturing business in Australia, the forest industries. It procrastinates; it changes. I think we have had five or six plans in the last seven years from this government. Now I understand they are looking at what they call a timber plan. Their backbenchers and other people are involved in discussing, not the forest industries strategy which they brought out in 1992, but some new timber plan for Australia.

I ask the government why it does not stick to its word. No matter what it does—in the last two or three years, in particular—it cannot be trusted. This budget is a clear example of a government that cannot be trusted. I believe that, as time goes on, the Australian people are not going to trust this government no matter what the Prime Minister says, or what the ministers of this government say.

It does not matter what one looks at. In education, down our way in Tasmania, we deserve to have an extra 2,000 places in our university and the government will not even give us 20. In regard to health insurance and Medicare in our area, it says there will be no increase in Medicare. What does it do? It puts Medicare up. And so it goes on. No matter what this government says, there is no reason for any Australian out there to believe it, particularly when it expands its belt, its budget, its spending and then expects everybody else to pull their belts in. I just hope that the Prime Minister will go to the election as soon as possible so that the Australian people can pass judgment on what I believe is a rotten budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96, which covers the administration of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I wish to bring to the attention of the House, through this Main Committee, a matter of national importance. I refer to the provision of secret funds paid by D. Toemin, Special Officer of the Embassy of the Republic of Suriname located in the Hague in the Netherlands. I will read the full text of the letter, which is marked `Deliver by hand' covering this transaction which is on the official letterhead of the Ambassador of the Republic of Suriname. The letter is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Ambassade van de Republiek Suriname
Alexander Gogelweg 2
2517 JH Den Haag
Cable: Suramb
Telex: 32220 Amsur NL

SPEECH.PARA: The letter has the word `VERZONDEN' marked on the top-right hand corner. It continues:
Uw kenmerk Uw brief van Ons kenmerk
Your reference PAR 67 Your letter dated OCT 1991 Our reference DESI 7
DEN HAAG. nov. 1991
Bijilage(n)
Enclosure(s)
Onderwerp Political payment
Subject ex Indonesia
EXCELLENCY!

PARA.TAB: We hereby convey a security case containing six hundred and fourty thousand United States Dollars******* (US$ 640.000.) as agreed with agent Mark Leibler.

SPEECH.PARA: The above mentioned funds should be distributed according to the schedules held by your Excellency.
Please sign the second letterhead copy and hand this personally to one of the two authorised Mossad agents
RECEIVED ABOVE FUNDS:

I hold two copies of this letter, which are identical in all respects except one. Copy 4 has no signature against the notation, `Received above funds', whilst against this notation on copy 2 there appears the signature of Mr Michael J Costello. The letter is also addressed to `Micael J. Costello esq., CBRR-7842-3988-AS, Australia'. This would appear to be a location code for Mr Costello at a Canberra address. It is the same on both copy 2 and copy 4 of the letter.

PARA.TAB: I especially draw the attention of the House through this Main Committee to the signature of Michael Costello on the letter, which is identical to the signature block applied on pages iv, 208 and 261 of the annual report of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for 1992-1993, placed on those pages in his official capacity as present secretary to the department.

Independent forensic tests by a recognised expert in this field reveal that not only are all these signatures identical, but also that there is no indication of document interference. Even if the signature block was applied by an unauthorised person to the Suriname letter, its presence must still be explained.

This particular signature block of Mr Costello—there are others—has been available for some years. In addition, further tests by an experienced microscopist show that both copies 2 and 4 of the Suriname letter are of the same paper, type and weight. It is worth noting that Mr Costello was overseas during the periods 16 to 26 October and 20 to 21 November 1991, which correlate with the October and November 1991 dates shown on the letter. According to the official visits record of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, he was the deputy secretary in 1991. During that year, he visited Chile in South America. Previously, again as the deputy secretary to the department, he had visited Brazil in 1989.

Noticeable too are the four security identification points placed in an identical or rectangular position on the top left-hand side of each copy of the letter. The intriguing references in this letter are `VERZONDEN' stamped on the letter, meaning to send or dispatch, and the word `Desi 7' may well refer to a correspondence series in relation to Suriname's former military strongman, who is still the central figure in Suriname's drug trade, Lieutenant Colonel Desi Bouterse.

Suriname is a small, remote country on the north-east coast of South America, with a population of over 400,000. The population includes many ethnic groupings descended from slaves, who were brought to Suriname by the former Dutch rulers from Africa, India and Indonesia. The capital of Suriname is Paramaribo, which may well relate to the reference `PAR 67' on each copy of the letter. Suriname is such a small country that there is no Australian diplomatic post there, although the Australian High Commission at Bridgetown in Barbados has a visiting, reporting and consular responsibility for Suriname.

It is Suriname's status as a drug source, a distribution country, which has been of particular concern to Dutch and US authorities. Over the last decade Suriname has also become notorious as a transit country for drug trafficking from Colombia and as a centre for cocaine production for Europe—in particular the Netherlands—and the United States.

In 1991 the US Drug Enforcement Administration, the DEA, visited Suriname to investigate drug trafficking. Over the last two years, the DEA has run a vigorous anti-narcotics program, in conjunction with the new government of Suriname, installed in 1991. The program includes the training of police, customs and military police officers to foster better cooperation among those services.

The key figure in Surinese politics is Lieutenant Colonel Desi Bouterse. As a sergeant major, he seized power in 1980, and ruled from 1980 to 1988. In this period he sought to align Suriname with Libya, Cuba and Grenada. After the invasion of Grenada by the United States in 1983, Bouterse turned to civilian rule, although he maintained the constitutional right to intervene in political affairs.

In 1986 Bouterse allegedly deposited several million dollars in the notorious and now defunct BCCI Bank in Miami. A contract written in Dutch and signed by Hank Goedschalk, the then governor of the Suriname Central Bank and a close associate of Bouterse, called for the Camari Corporation, based in the Netherlands Antilles, to lend the Surinese government $US200 million in cash. In the same year, 1991, the Dutch foreign intelligence agency, the IDB and the Dutch intelligence agency, the BVD, began investigating drug trafficking, especially cocaine coming from Colombia to Suriname and going on to Holland and the United States.

In 1986 Bouterse's right-hand man, Captain Etienne Boerenveen, was sentenced to 12 years in prison for conspiring to use Suriname's air fields as bases for exporting cocaine to the United States. According to intelligence reports, Bouterse paid $US600,000 for Boerenveen's defence.

One of the partners in the conspiracy claimed that Bouterse and Boerenveen intended to channel the profits into the country's economy and split the balance. Boerenveen was sentenced to 12 years in prison and released early in 1991. On his release, he was promoted by Bouterse from captain to commandant and appointed commander of the military police and central intelligence services of Suriname's armed forces. In 1990, the Netherlands, faced with a growing drug problem arising from drugs from Suriname, expelled two diplomats, who had ties to Bouterse, for drug related activities.

Desi Bouterse resigned as Suriname's army chief in November 1992. He established himself as an international businessman and went on to form the National Democratic Party, the NDP. Despite his formal departure from the military, Bouterse has maintained a well-armed private army and still has a significant number of sympathisers in the armed forces.

As head of the NDP, Bouterse has used his position to run a populist campaign against the unpopular economic austerity programs foisted on President Ronald Venetiaan by the IMF and the World Bank. His political rhetoric is characterised by a `narco-nationalist' style, mainly directed against the Dutch. Regrettably, Bouterse has indeed increased his power after the death, in December 1993, of Pablo Escobar Gaviria, who was the head of Colombia's notorious Medellin cartel.

The political power base of Bouterse is not to be underestimated. His money, which is derived from the drug trade, keeps many followers loyal, especially in the local police force. The Medellin cartel was already in decline prior to Escobar's death. Its operations have diminished or collapsed into the business network of the Cali cartel. Escobar had been a regular visitor to Suriname from 1987 to 1989, and there were several meetings between Bouterse and Escobar. Bouterse continues to control the jungle infrastructure which facilitates the transhipment of narcotics.

Etienne Boerenveen, Bouterse's previously referred to right-hand man, is still currently a senior adviser to the defence ministry. After serving out his prison sentence in Miami, Boerenveen had no trouble re-entering Suriname's military structure. In effect, he is the day-to-day liaison for Bouterse to the armed forces brass, though in fairness it must be said that not everyone in the Suriname military is corrupt.
According to the 1994 US Department of State Report on international strategy to combat narcotics trafficking, Suriname is not itself a money laundering centre. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The non-convertibility of Suriname's currency and its limited financial market steer money launderers elsewhere.

Although Suriname is remote from financial scrutiny, its banking system does have representatives abroad. Due to its status as a former Dutch colony, it has links to both the Netherlands and Indonesia. In fact, those of Javanese descent make up over 16 per cent of the population.

PARA.TAB: Significantly, Dutch investigators have established leads that Bouterse's gang has tied up with a similar network of Indonesian military officers. The major lead is the NV Musa Indo-Suriname investment group, which in August 1993 asked President Venetiaan if it could buy the rights to Suriname's trees. It was eventually granted 375,000 acres near the Guyana border, where Bouterse allegedly plays a major role.

Bearing these comments about Desi Bouterse, his associates and networks in mind, I turn now to the documents I am specifically dealing with today. In this context, the following questions arise. First, why is Mr Mark Leibler, a prominent Melbourne tax lawyer who at one stage served on three separate advisory committees to the Commissioner of Taxation and who was a major witness before the Public Accounts Committee inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office which took place from 1991 to 93, acting as an agent in a major financial transaction involving the Israeli intelligence service, the Mossad, and the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Michael Costello?

Second, what is the `distribution schedule' held by Mr Costello and referred to in the two copies of the letter, and who is on it? Third, was any of the $US640,000 paid to Mr Costello for his personal use, and if so, why? Fourth, was any of the $US640,000 paid to Mr Costello acting as an agent for the Labor Party for election or other purposes? Fifth, and alternatively, was any of this money paid to Mr Costello for services rendered to any foreign government or foreign intelligence service? Sixth, was any of the money derived from the proceeds of crime, most especially drug trafficking, as Suriname is well known as a drug source? Finally, is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the involvement of his permanent head in this transaction, and if not, why not?

The Australian of 10 August 1993 described Mr Costello as an `unusual diplomat'. He certainly is. He is allegedly the architect of the unfulfilled Cambodian peace plan, yet he has served only 3 1/2 years abroad as a diplomat. Costello has no experience in Cambodian affairs and has not lived in Asia. He speaks no Asian language. The Australian of 26 January 1990 cited a journalist as commenting:

SPEECH.PARA: He [Costello] is Asia illiterate. And yet he is supposed to bring peace to Cambodia. I find it very odd.'

Indeed. The truth is that Mr Costello is a monument to mafia mateship. The government's reaction to the public disclosure of Costello's relationship with Valeriy Zemskov, an officer of the KGB's elite special reserve, with whom Costello shared many long lunches, dinners and animated conversations, was a typical case of mafia mateship. The government reached for the whitewash brush to paint over the truth of the Costello-Zemskov relationship, yet a cabinet in-confidence minute to the then foreign minister, Mr Hayden, of 11 March 1986, clearly showed that MI5 had warned ASIO of Zemskov's real status in January 1985.

PARA.TAB: Since Costello's unprecedented promotion to the position of secretary, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has leaked so much it is in danger of becoming incontinent. In the second half of 1994, we saw the leaking of the most sensitive Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade documents in relation to the Cambodia crisis. Costello himself has been suspected and interviewed, on previous occasions, by the Australian Federal Police in relation to the disclosure of official information.

ASIO and ASIS have undergone serious inquiries and reports of both inquiries are most disturbing. It has long been suspected that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should also be the subject of an inquiry. It is highly unlikely that any inquiry could be conducted as long as Mr Costello remained secretary to the department.

I emphasise that I am seeking to table these documents in the national interest. There are many fine people in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who serve Australia's interests well, at home and abroad. They have a right to know the truth about their departmental head. The Australian people have a right to know the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.

The minimal response the government should make is to ensure that Mr Costello is immediately stood down as the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, pending non-partisan investigation into the serious issues I have raised today. To assist in this process, I am sending the Hansard record of this speech to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. In respect of Mr Costello himself, I expect a comprehensive explanation, not the waving of his `good behaviour' plaque from certain ASIO officers.

Full and proper investigation of serious issues of national concern such as this—not government attempts to close off debate and curb press freedom by gaoling journalists, as we are witnessing, for instance, in respect of the proposed ASIS legislation—is essential. This will be difficult for the government to do on this issue, as I will have much more to reveal at a later date.
In conclusion, I seek leave to table the two copies of the letter I referred to earlier in this speech.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt that was a sincere speech by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred). But it carried extraordinary innuendos, and it seemed to me to be a misuse of the kinds of privileges that we, as parliamentarians, have. It was certainly a very distasteful attack on an eminent public servant of integrity. Therefore, I request that significant disappointment with the speech be noted.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—The member for Fraser, under indulgence, is welcome to make that observation. I listened intently to what the member for Deakin was saying. I recognise that, had he not made those comments here, he could have made them at some other forum. He possibly could not have related them to an appropriations speech in the House, but they could have been made, for example, in an adjournment speech. I endeavoured to be careful. I would have interrupted the member for Deakin had I felt that he had moved into some sub judice area, which I thought he avoided doing. Given his experience, I would have expected him to avoid doing so. I cannot comment objectively on the remarks made by the member for Fraser, except to say that I heard what the member for Deakin had to say and felt that he had the right to express those sentiments in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's budget, which we are debating, is now at an interesting stage. We have the national account figures for the last quarter, we have had the April unemployment figures and, this Thursday, the May unemployment figure will be released. We have just had the OECD report on Australia, and the trade figures have just come in.

PARA.TAB: So, in total, we now have quite a range of indicators in relation to the state of the economy and just how good the government's budget and its forecasts are, in relation to the budget surplus, interest rates, employment levels, the balance of payments and the value of the dollar, and in relation to just how sustainable our economic growth is and at what level that sustainability is.

The government tries to give the impression that this is a country that is doing well, and to confirm its projection it then makes some comfortable comparisons. It uses its previous record—which included the `recession that we had to have'—of past mismanagement of this government and what that has meant for this country. It uses selective comparisons with the OECD. It refers to the broad GDP growth, where one has to take into account that Australia is one of the few countries in the world that still has a significant migration program and therefore our growth rate has to be higher than that of most of our competitors if we are to be able to sustain real growth on a per capita basis. That partly explains the paradox that we consistently have higher unemployment figures than many other comparable countries, yet it is claimed that our growth rate is also higher. But the comparison is never made with the east Asian countries, the ones with which we have to compete, whether it be on growth rates, on employment levels or on savings and investment.

One little element that comes out of the budget is the increase in the company tax rate by nine per cent from 33 to 36 per cent. There have already been a number of statements from Asian business and government people that any chance Australia might have had of making itself a regional business centre as an alternative to an Asian country is now gone, both because of the higher company tax rate and because of the uncertainty as to what Australia's policies long term are—it is only a couple of years since it was stated that this would be the appropriate rate.

Then people would say that that is an unfair comparison with our Asian neighbours because they are in an earlier phase of economic growth and therefore we should be looking at more mature economies, similar to ours. One can look at the other Anglo countries, perhaps, because it is generally considered that these are not at the forefront of economic development at the present time. One can look at the OECD and also quote comparisons and averages on interest rates, unemployment levels and so forth.

In particular, however, one can look at New Zealand. New Zealand is even more an Anglo country than we are and New Zealand had its budget last Thursday. Any comparison with New Zealand should be very comfortable indeed, because with the exception of some gas New Zealand does not have the mineral wealth that Australia does; that is our major source of export income. It has a far narrower range of agricultural products than we do; it does not have any real grains industry or subtropical agriculture. Because of the small population it has no real economy of scale for its manufacturing industries. In fact, New Zealand, it has been stated, would be the first country to slide from being a developed country into being a developing country again.

One may compare the New Zealand budget of last Thursday night with our budget. This affords a very fascinating comparison between a country that really is doing well and a country—Australia—that is sliding, to the detriment of its people and its economy generally. It has been stated in this budget that there will be a budget surplus, after allowing for asset sales, of $718 million. Elsewhere in the budget documents the deficit is classed as $8.2 billion, as a more real deficit. If we read elsewhere we find that the economics section of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, for example, would put the budget deficit at $12.5 billion.

Let us look at New Zealand. Its budget surplus for 1995-96 will be $3.3 billion. There are no asset sales—no Qantas being put up for sale for the umpteenth time. The New Zealanders can quote very accurately, because of the procedures they now adopt in their country and their policies, that that budget surplus will increase significantly to $7.8 billion by 1997-98. They will be able to have some tax cuts as well; those, obviously, will be coming in the next few months, getting closer to their election. They will be able to be financed from the future surpluses, and those surpluses will still be there. If one compares that $3.3 billion budget surplus and Australia's $718 million surplus, at the best—or, at the worst, $12.5 billion deficit—then those figures become even more alarming from an Australian point of view in view of the size of the New Zealand economy relative to the Australian economy. It would probably be only about one-sixth or one-seventh of our economy.

In addition to that, comparing the budgets in another way, in the Australian budget of 1983-84 nine per cent of total budget outlays were for capital expenditure. Total budget outlays for capital works in this coming year in Australia will be negative. They will move into a position of disinvestment. Yet New Zealand is still able to provide real investment capital and have a budget surplus in that country, for example, several hundred million dollars extra for roadworks plus extra money for research.

If one looks at taxation levels, the highest personal income tax level in New Zealand is 33 per cent. Australia's tax level is about 15 per cent higher and New Zealand is talking about tax cuts in the next few months. In both countries growth rate forecasts for this coming financial year are less than the current year. New Zealand has had a growth rate of 5.3 per cent for the current year and it is claiming in its budget documents that it will come down to three per cent. Depending on whether or not we believe that the March quarter figure is the real figure for the next 12 months, we have already slipped to 3.75 per cent for the last quarter on an annualised basis. The projection in the budget was that we would be at 3.75 per cent for all of the next financial year, but the reality or the trend is that that last quarter increase is now so low that, if it continues, our real growth rate for the next 12 months in this country is going to be 2.25 per cent, not 3.75 per cent.

That carries with it very severe implications for the level of the budget deficit because taxation income will be down, welfare payments will be up and unemployment must start to increase. To maintain the unemployment level at the current rate, Australia needs growth of at least 3 1/2 per cent in the economy. It means that when New Zealand looks ahead it is able to claim, I believe fairly consistently, that it will average a four per cent growth rate over the next few years. Australia is certainly not able to claim that. That is the difference in the growth rates between the two countries.

It has already had an impact on unemployment levels. If we compare Australia with the OECD generally, we have averaged two per cent higher for the last calendar year, we are 1 1/2 per cent higher so far this year on projections and we are three to four per cent ahead of the United States. Even if the United States has a falling employment level at the present time, it has a lot of surplus ahead of us. New Zealand has about a two per cent lower level of unemployment or higher employment figures than we have. Many would say that countries such as the United States and New Zealand have far more genuine figures for employment levels than Australia because it is calculated that up to two per cent of our people in employment in Australia are on make-work schemes, training schemes and so forth, whereas New Zealand and the United States do not have anywhere near the same degree of those programs. Also, our definition of employment is a very unrealistic one because anyone who does any paid work at all is classed as being employed.

Australia's real level of unemployment is about four per cent higher than that of New Zealand at the present time. In order to look at what that means, I would like to quote Max Walsh from the Age last Friday. Referring to the OECD report, he made the point that our investment has been very low and that New Zealand, the United States and other countries have higher levels of investment than we do. Then in the last paragraph he said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the OECD report did not say, but which is central to the whole issue of business investment is that if the lower level of increase in our net capital stock condemns us to a growth limit of `a little over three per cent', then unemployment by 2000 will not be reduced, as the Government claims, to a 5 per cent figure, but be permanently stuck at double that figure.
That is at about 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: If we look at interest rates, New Zealand is currently about two per cent less than Australia and that has been consistently the case for the last four years. The United States is even lower: it is about 2 1/2 per cent lower than Australia. We have to look at what that means regarding encouragement for investment. If we look at what the rest of the world thinks of us and our future compared with New Zealand, a few years ago the Australian dollar was worth 20c more than the New Zealand dollar, today it is worth 7c more than the New Zealand dollar and the New Zealanders are confident that, within the next few years, we will be trading at par, something that has never happened in the relative growth rates, outlooks or prospects for our two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That helps our exports.

—It does not necessarily help our exports. What it does mean is that it condemns us to a declining standard of living relative to other countries. As we buy more and more of our inputs from overseas—and we are doing that and it is one of the problems we have with our balance of trade figures—it means that they become more and more expensive. I believe in the long term—and you may feel that is a surprising thing for a National Party person to say—that a weak dollar indicates a declining standard of living, not an ability to help exports. If I had more time, I could go into the detail of what this means—for example, with imported inputs that are necessary for some of our agricultural and other exports.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the Australian dollar and its volatility we should also look at our trade balance. New Zealand's current account deficit is about 2.2 per cent of its GDP and improving; ours is almost down to our worst figure, about six per cent of GDP. That is a $27 billion current account deficit for the 12 months. One of the little ironies is that, because of the wool stockpile and because we are able to sell from the stockpile partly due to the drought and the reduced wool production, the increased wool exports so far this calendar year have increased by half our merchandise trade for this year. It is one of those ironic things: what was a negative is now a real positive for Australia.

But it does raise the question of a run on the dollar. It raises the question of high interest rates and, in comparing the two countries, it comes back to how much further ahead New Zealand is with its fiscal responsibility act. It means it has far greater transparency, accuracy and accountability in the presentation of its figures. It means that its reserve bank act, which must concentrate on lower levels of inflation, is having its impact. If one argues that New Zealand has been hard on welfare for some of its people, there is nothing worse in welfare than people without a job. That is the worst thing any country can ever give to its people. To conclude, I quote Sir Roger Douglas, a leading New Zealand Labor minister for finance—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not now.

—Not now. I agree with that. In fact, it is also critical of the New Zealand nationals and their budget. I quote what he says about Australia and its Labor government when he compares the two countries:

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing more crude and brutal than a government that seeks electoral advantage by refusing to make economic reforms that are desperately needed.

That is really a good bullseye against this government and its total economic program. It means that, by its failure to get all of these settings right—and that is the term the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) likes to use—this government has condemned Australians to a low level of sustainable growth. This means that unemployment will increase again, there will be a further slide in our relative standard of living compared with other OECD countries, or other countries generally, and the gap between rich and poor will increase.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to contribute to the budget debate in the Main Committee chamber today. I think a lot of people were looking for some hope from the government when the Treasurer (Mr Willis) brought down the budget just a few short weeks ago. Since the budget, like other honourable members, I have had the opportunity of consulting widely in my electorate. Normally, when one finds a government initiative, one sees that there is a cross-section of opinion in the community. From the government's point of view, unfortunately, in respect of this budget, I have yet to come across one constituent who is in any way, shape or form convinced that the government has brought down a reasonable document or is convinced of the government's bona fides.

PARA.TAB: In fact, I have spoken to media outlets and they have conducted surveys of various constituents in my electorate. It is fairly clear that the government simply has been unable to convince the people of Fisher that this budget is what the country needs and that this budget is, in fact, anything other than a fraud. I suspect that the people of my electorate—and, indeed, people throughout the whole country—will condemn this government, because it has failed in the budget to address the major problems that we have as a nation.

Of course, included in those problems is the situation where, after 12 years of Labor government, we have about 800,000 or 900,000 people officially out of work. We have probably close to two million people unable to find sufficient work. As my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who spoke before me, said, the figures released by the government in relation to unemployment are not genuine. The only people who are, in fact, recorded as being unemployed are those receiving jobstart, newstart or youth training allowances, and those people who work even some small number of hours per week are not deemed to be in the system. Indeed, if a person is not in receipt of social security, that person is deemed to be employed. Of course, people who are in training programs are also deemed to be employed.

I know that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who is sitting opposite me, would prefer the government to come clean. I know he has a keen interest in the issue of unemployment. It is tragic that, after 12 years of Labor government, we have a situation where the government is, firstly, not prepared to do anything about the problem and, secondly, not even prepared to admit the magnitude of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —But a lot of people in training programs are employed.
—Those people in training programs might well be taken off the dole queue for the short term—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! Save it for a separate meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is on a short-term basis but, of course, they go back on the dole queue when they have finished their training program. From looking at some of the reports in the newspapers following the budget, it is fairly clear that the indications I have had from my own constituency are, indeed, feelings similar to those being expressed not only by newspapers but by people throughout the country. I think the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), summed it up rather nicely in the Age on 10 May when he said that the federal budget is `like a cheap paint job slapped on to a used car to cover a dodgy sale'. Its specific purpose is to provide a quick cover-up job to attempt to deceive the Australian people long enough for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to get to an election. It is fairly clear that this budget is designed to cover up the real situation long enough for the Prime Minister to be able to dash to the polls.

PARA.TAB: The West Australian, in an editorial dated 10 May, had the headline `Budget surplus has dubious base'. We know that not only is it dubious but it is also fraudulent, because the government claimed that it had a budget surplus of some $700 million plus, whereas the reality is that there is a very substantial budget deficit. The West Australian editorial reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Prime Minister Paul Keating has conjured up a surplus in Labor's final Budget before the next election—
I hope that it is Labor's final budget—period!—
but a sullen electorate will take a lot of convincing that it is real and not another economic illusion.
Evidence to support the claimed shift of the nation's finances back into the black is flimsy.

I think the West Australian summed it up. The Hobart Mercury was concentrating on the Prime Minister's further broken election promise when the so-called l-a-w tax cuts, in fact, finally became an l-i-e. It headlined its editorial by saying:
Tax cuts a bad J-O-K-E. Prime Minister Paul Keating believes last night's Federal Budget will not hurt his government's re-election chances.
It is an opinion which reflects just how distant Canberra is from the rest of Australia.

We are going to have to wait until the next election for the government to finally really appreciate how Emperor Paul Keating is indeed out of touch with the average Australian battler—the ordinary person who, in many cases, might have a job but does not earn enough to provide his or her family with an adequate standard of living: the working poor. This is a situation that we have not previously had in this country, where employed people who work a full week are simply unable to bring home enough income to provide a reasonable standard of living for their families.

PARA.TAB: The Financial Review had a headline `Keating's budget gamble' and the article continued to bag the government's deception. On 10 May, the Age had the headline `A budget designed to win the next election' and so it goes on. We have a situation where the editorial writers have not been convinced of the government's bona fides. The people of my electorate, and people throughout the country, have not been convinced that the government is genuine or that the government has brought down a budget that this country needs. The government continues to walk around with its head in the clouds, seeking to deceive the Australian people.

On 29 May, I was reading the Courier-Mail, as most Queensland members regularly do, and I found, hidden away on page 15, an article with the headline `Asian cheers for our budget.' This article was written by a gentleman called Tye Kim Khiat, a Singapore based business writer. I thought that perhaps the government had somehow found someone prepared to praise the government for what it has not done. Mr Tye's article was interesting because he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is considerable cheer in Asia of late, thanks to the corporate tax hike provided for in the recent Australian Budget.

PARA.TAB: As it is, Australia is far from competitive vis-a-vis the region, but the tax hike could have driven the final nail into the coffin of Australian competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at the various rates of corporate tax being applied in countries in the Asia-Pacific region, it is fairly clear that this hike in the corporate tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent is not going to help the government, despite the short-term windfall it will bring. In the long term, it will make it clear to the countries of South-East Asia and the Pacific region that we are not serious about becoming a major financial centre, that we are not serious about being competitive. The story in the Courier-Mail of 29 May, under that heading `Asian cheers for our budget', indicates that Asians are cheering for our budget because of the damage it does to Australia.

PARA.TAB: The 1995-96 federal budget is a blatantly political budget which mirrors the end of the Whitlam government. We find tax hikes. We find unfunded promises offering nothing positive for the residents of my electorate and nothing positive for the other people resident in Australia. Through anticipated asset sales, paper shuffles and a cooking of the books, the government has falsely claimed a $780 million surplus. Disregarding the government's accounting tricks, that type of claim would have sent a company director to gaol. In reality, this budget does not have a surplus of $780 million but a true deficit of $8.2 billion. If anyone in the country had any doubt at all that this government could not be believed, they only have to look at the budget delivered by the Treasurer a short time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the IMF and the OECD wrong?

—The situation is that this government simply cannot be trusted. The people of Australia cannot trust this government. This government breaks promises. This government has brought down a budget which, as the member opposite knows, is fiscally irresponsible. It is a budget which Australia does not need. It is short-term budget which is designed to get the government past the next election. The government is going to fail because the people of Australia are not convinced by what the Prime Minister has been saying following the budget. They are not convinced of the figures delivered by the Treasurer on election night. I think this budget really is the government's last hurray.

PARA.TAB: This government has sought to deceive the Australian people for far too long. Anyone who assesses the budget figures will see the duplicity, the deception and the downright inaccuracy in this budget. It does absolutely nothing to improve the situation in Australia. It does absolutely nothing to bring about the policy changes that we need to enable Australia to become competitive and it does absolutely nothing to assist Australians to get a job. This budget is once again nothing more than a cynical attempt by Labor to lie its way into winning the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by expressing dismay at the processes of the debate surrounding this budget. It is a classical demonstration of the contempt with which the Labor government now holds the parliament that this budget debate has been moved off to the Main Committee, that speakers are restricted in their time and that, when the consideration in detail comes on later today, the amount of time available for debate will be almost nil. The speakers list for today's debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) shows 26 members from the opposition but not a single government member. That says something about where the budget stands: 26 opposition members have plenty of things to say but not one government member is here prepared to defend the budget. There is no economic minister present to listen to the words of the elected representatives.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the presence of the chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore)—no doubt the environment is an important element of this budget. However, I hope that his voice can be heard loud and clear in portraying back to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) the anger in the speeches that are being made and the condemnation of so many aspects of this budget. The Treasurer himself should be here to listen: he should be participating in this debate; and I think it is appalling that he is not.

When we look to the consideration of the bill in detail tonight, 10 minutes are allowed for the consideration in detail of groups of three or four departments at a time. What a mockery of the words `consideration in detail'—10 minutes for three departments! In fact, my own area of interest, consumer affairs, is not listed at all and presumably has got to be dealt with under the estimates for Attorney-General's, along with two or three other portfolios—a total of 10 minutes allocated. That is not consideration in detail. That is contempt for the parliamentary process; that is contempt for democracy. That is the very sound reason why this government will be thrown out of office at the very first available opportunity.

The fact is that, as a result of this budget, consumers will pay more for almost every single thing that they buy. There will be increased taxes on a whole range of merchandise and goods. There will be the obvious increases in tax on motor vehicles and building materials and tobacco, which will be passed directly onto consumers, but the higher taxes applying to business will also be reflected in higher prices charged for goods and services as business naturally seeks to recover the extra cost of these tax slugs. The higher Medicare levy is just another tax increase. Labor's election promised tax cuts have become record tax increases. The five per cent sales tax on the family car, which will increase to six per cent on 1 July, will alone add 0.3 per cent to the consumer price index. Ironically, the budget will not affect luxury cars except, of course, for the one per cent increase that has been put in place from a previous budget.

The general sales taxes that were foreshadowed in earlier budgets, but which take effect on 1 July 1995, will certainly have an effect on the price of every item in every store. In fact, one of the big increases in budget revenue for the government is in this area of sales tax receipts, which will go up from $11.6 billion to $14.2 billion, an increase of 22.3 per cent. This is a big taxing budget—indeed, the biggest taxing budget in our history. When one looks at the increase in government revenues from $110 billion to $125.5 billion, it is only two budgets ago that $100 billion was collected for the first time. Now we are already up to $125 billion. The government's tax revenue share of GDP goes from 24.1 per cent to 25.3 per cent—and that figure comes directly from the government's own budget statements. The growth in revenue was up 7.9 per cent in the last budget. That was bad enough, but it is up another 8.9 per cent in this budget. So this is indeed a big taxing budget and it is ordinary Australians who will pay these taxes every time they go to the store, every time they want to buy something. That clearly has an impact on the whole way in which business is done in this country.

Of course, Labor is developing a well deserved reputation for the centrality of taxes in its economic policy. No matter what the economic problem, Labor's solution is always higher taxes. The government was concerned about the recession five years ago, the recession that it would not let happen. Then it was a recession for which it pulled the levers, and it had to come. The solution in those times was mini-statements and the like to impose higher taxes. The government said that it needed higher taxes at that stage so that it could stimulate the economy, forgetting that those taxes are paid by those who could create the enthusiasm and initiative to get the economy moving again.

According to the Australian Labor Party, the solution to the recession was higher taxes. Then, when rapid growth became the problem—exactly the opposite to a recession—the solution yet again was higher taxes because the government needed to tax people more to slow the economy. It was the opposite problem, with exactly the same solution—higher taxes.

When the problem was one million unemployed, again it was said that we needed higher taxes so that the government could fund job creation schemes. It forgot that those taxes would be paid by the very businesses which could have created the jobs which would have provided long-term, lasting employment. Again the government had turned to the same solution—higher taxes.

When the problem was a record current account deficit—which is still a problem—yet again the government's solution was higher taxes, this time to depress demand.
