It forgot that those higher taxes would be paid by the very people who could be exporting more and thus improving our balance of payments through greater overseas sales.

When the problem was a massive budget deficit, again the solution was higher taxes because the government simply could not afford its wild spending programs. It has forgotten that, instead of higher taxes, one solution would be to cut its own expenditure levels. If the government were to take that sort of action it would easily achieve the kind of balanced budget which is so essential.

The intellectual dexterity that the government manages to produce to justify each new round of tax increases is amazing. No matter what the problem, it has exactly the same solution—the people will have higher taxes imposed upon them. Only the current government could hold the view that the country is better off when it pays more and more taxes to a central government to do things which, more often than not, the people of this country could do so much better themselves.

The budget is noted for its so-called `surplus', which was meant to surprise the community. However, the effect of that surplus was to lead the public to the very justifiable view that the whole budget is based on fudged figures—smoke and mirrors and the like—because in reality no-one believes that the government is capable of balancing its budget and no-one believes the figures that are in this document.

The budget has been balanced in two ways. Firstly, massive tax hikes are included in the budget. I have already mentioned the 22.3 per cent increase in sales tax, but other taxes are going up as well. Individual income tax is up by 13.6 per cent. The Medicare levy is up by 18.4 per cent. Company tax is up by 15.4 per cent. The superannuation funds tax is up by 13.2 per cent. The fringe benefits tax is up another 4.4 per cent, after it went up by over 100 per cent in last year's budget. The fuel excise—that great milch cow of Labor governments—is up another 7.7 per cent. Other excise duties are up 8.8 per cent. There are massive tax increases right across the board.

The other element that has created this artificial surplus is the big sell-off of government assets. Each year the federal Labor government attempts to balance its budget by selling off more and more of our national assets. Over recent years Labor has budgeted to sell the Australian National Line, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, the Commonwealth uranium stockpile, the war service land settlement scheme, the Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline system, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the Commonwealth phosphate rock stockpile, overseas embassy buildings—including those in Tokyo and Paris—the defence service home loans scheme, the Avalon airfield, the ACT housing loan assistance scheme, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, repatriation hospitals, Brisbane airport land, Australian Airlines, Qantas, the Commonwealth accommodation and catering services, Williamstown dockyard, government buildings in Sydney and Melbourne, the Commonwealth Bank, Cockatoo Island, the Anzac rifle range, Australian Industry Development Corporation, Aerospace Technologies of Australia, Newington Armament Depot, and this time 18,200 cars as well. The list goes on and on.

The government is selling off the family silver. It would not necessarily be a major issue if that money were then being used for some constructive purpose such as to retire debt, or if it were being used to re-position our economy to be more aggressive and more competitive in the years ahead. Sadly, all of these sales have been budgeted to pay for this year's unemployment benefits and this year's welfare bills. The proceeds of all those sales are being used to keep the budget alive. They are not being used to positively restructure our national economy to make our country profitable in the future.

Furthermore, the government has been a dreadful salesman. It has not been able to sell many of the things it has on the list. It has not even been able to give some of them away, as the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) said on one occasion. The government has an appalling record in this area and, in fact, Qantas is being sold for the fourth time in this budget.

If you look at the government's sale record, it has only once in the last seven years achieved anything like its targeted budget estimates. In 1990-91, it managed $162 million out of a billion dollars worth of budgeted sales; in 1991-92, $311 million out of $625 million; in 1992-93, $811 million out of $1,600 million. In 1993-94, it actually sold $2.4 billion and budgeted to receive $2.4 billion. Last year, the classic of them all, $55 million was all that was achieved in asset sales, despite budgeting to receive $2.45 billion. So who believes the government when it claims it is going to sell $5.25 billion worth of assets this year? It simply will not happen, the budget will not be balanced, and so its only redeeming feature, the element that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) boasted of so proudly on budget night, will again be a dismal failure, and with it the whole basic structure of this budget.

A few days ago, the Prime Minister told small business that it does not get any better than this. The small businessmen in my electorate would say that they have known plenty of times in their life when it has been very much better than this. It may well be true to say that this Prime Minister and this government cannot get it any better than this, but that is not good enough for Australia. If this is the best they can do, it is high time they gave it away and passed government to people who can achieve better things for our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96 to make some comments in relation to what is probably Europe's worst crisis since the Second World War, the crisis in the Balkans. Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, as you would know and others would know, I have taken a deep interest in this particular issue for some time. One of the reasons that I first took an interest in this particular issue is because, in the recent political history of Europe, particularly from the 1970s onwards, the break-up of the Yugoslavian federation and the ensuing problems that this may have caused obviously would have been a consideration in any particular study of eastern European strategy and developments.

PARA.TAB: The situation in relation to the former Yugoslavia is of particular note. Those of us who are perhaps not adherents of but who are certainly interested in the writings of Alvin Toffler and others who have made some predictions in relation to this type of development would know that some time ago, I think in his book The Third Wave, even perhaps as far back as Future Shock, Toffler predicted that there would be a fractionalisation in nationalism, in particular in eastern Europe. He predicted, as some others have predicted, that you would see virtually a continuation of what was occurring in the late 19th century with the nationalist revolutions, which were effectively forestalled by the First World War and then the Bolshevik revolution in Russia in 1917. Following that, there was the imposition of totalitarian regimes in some of those nations. This was seen as a future trend by commentators such as Toffler and others, but unfortunately it seems not to have been seen by those who had the responsibility for devising strategy and foreign policy on the part of many of the Western powers, in whose interest it would have been to take a greater interest in what is now occurring in the Balkans, but what could have been foreseen some time ago.

I visited the region several times as part of my interest in the ensuing developments since the incipient independence movements took place in 1990 and 1991 in Slovenia, Croatia, more latterly Bosnia-Herzegovina, and the other former Yugoslav republics since basically the collapse of the post-Tito order in Yugoslavia. There are some who would argue that as far back as the latter part of Tito's rule of Yugoslavia it should have been plainly clear that, once Tito's rule and authority collapsed or changed in a marked way, there was likely to be a disintegration of what was basically a federation of quite distinctly different nationalities.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—I apologise for interrupting the honourable member for Moore, but we are on the appropriations debate and I tend not to find his contribution all that relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Moore is speaking to the Foreign Affairs appropriations, is he not? He is referring to them, as he is entitled to in the course of his speech.
—I thank the deputy whip for that assistance.
—You are right. It came as something of a surprise.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I appreciate that. Quite clearly, in any consideration of Australia's own budget and its own foreign policy—which is funded through budgetary allocations—this crisis is a matter of grave concern and a matter that should occupy not just the fleeting thoughts of our foreign minister. What is now Europe's gravest security crisis since the Second World War is completely baffling to the minds and the strategies of those experts who in many cases have had a long time and long experience in dealing with the vagaries of political development in the region.

PARA.TAB: I wanted to point out that the disintegration of the Federation of Yugoslavia should have been foreseen a long time before. One could argue that there are number of influences that prevented people from seeing that clearly. One was the enormous propaganda effort by the government, the agencies and the foreign affairs department of the former Federation of Yugoslavia to try to convince people that all was well within the federation.

We are now seeing basically the results—the gruesome results, in many cases terrifying and nightmarish in their imagery—of this lack of preparation on the part of Western powers, in particular the United Nations and the European Union, to deal with this quite clearly foreseeable trend in the Balkans. What is happening in front of our eyes on television night after night, including the kidnapping of a large number of United Nations peacekeepers by the Bosnian Serbs, is something that is also a long foreseeable outcome of the lack of action and the lack of willpower on the part of the Western nations.

For a long time I and others have supported the view that there ought to have been a greater exertion of the will of the Western powers, essentially to prevent or to stop barbarous and inhumane behaviour on the part of those responsible for aggression and territorial acquisition, in particular on the territory of Bosnia-Herzegovina. Those who know the history would know that Bosnia-Herzegovina was recognised as a sovereign nation by the United Nations in 1992 and as a consequence of its recognition it was entitled to have protected by its fellow member nations its sovereign boundaries and its integrity as a nation.

We have seen 45 separate resolutions by the United Nations dealing with the Bosnia and Herzegovina crisis since 1992-93. I would challenge any member of any government, other than those, perhaps, who are instrumental in drafting those UN resolutions by negotiation, to describe now exactly what the role of Unprofor is in the nation of Bosnia-Herzegovina.

In the absence of any real effort or will to properly resolve the questions of territory, the integrity of the nation of Bosnia-Herzegovina, aggression, the shelling of the cities of Sarajevo, Tuzla, Bihac and others by the Bosnian Serbs, and the kidnapping and holding of UN peacekeepers, which is a flagrantly provocative act on the part of the Bosnian Serb forces, the sanctions that have been applied and have prevented the government of Bosnia-Herzegovina from being able to protect its own sovereign territory should be lifted, in order to allow that government to be able to provide protection to its citizens and order to its territory, and to be able to protect and survey its own frontiers.

It is under those circumstances that I call, for the nth time, for those sanctions to be lifted immediately, so that the government of Bosnia-Herzegovina can act as it should be able to do—as a sovereign government of a sovereign nation, which is a sovereign member of the United Nations—and can protect its own citizens from barbarous terrorist acts on the part of the Bosnian Serbs.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! I will interrupt the speaker there.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 2.46 to 4.35 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was enlarging on my views on the current crisis in Bosnia and Herzegovina. As I mentioned, it is one of the gravest crises facing Europe, and the rest of the world for that matter, since the Second World War in terms of security and peace and in relation to the long-term prospects for a peaceful solution to the ructions caused as a result of the collapse of communist regimes in the Soviet Union and former eastern European satellites and in other nations that had communist regimes. I concluded before the break by making the observation for the nth time that the sanctions are preventing the government of Bosnia and Herzegovina from being able to arm itself and to have the capacity to provide for peace and security and its own self-determination. The control of its own territory and the surveillance and control of its own frontiers are an absolute necessity. There must be a lifting of these sanctions before any semblance of order can be restored to the region.

PARA.TAB: It has been an absolute fallacy on the part of the United Nations and the European Union and those other nations that have taken an interest in this particular matter that the sanctions have contributed towards a peaceful outcome. The capture, the holding as hostages and the kidnapping of United Nations peacekeepers by the Bosnian Serbs has been an outrage perpetrated on the rest of the world by a group that is terroristic and has shown its flagrant contempt for the rules of civilised behaviour that most of the rest of the world hold.
On that concluding note, I can only reiterate my earlier call for a lifting of those sanctions as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is widely recognised that what we need in Australia is a strong and sustained lift in savings both public and private. In his budget speech on 9 May 1995, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the principal objectives of this budget is to meet the medium term imperative of improving national saving to maintain investment and employment through the 1990s and beyond.

If that is the case, this budget, on the government's own terms, has been a signal failure. Dr Vince FitzGerald observed in his national saving report to the Treasurer in June 1993 that our national savings level has fallen to 16 per cent of GDP, lower than it has been since Federation, except during the two world wars and during the Great Depression. This is cause for concern in itself, since we already have a very high foreign debt and a high current account deficit adding constantly to it. Dr FitzGerald concluded that, if we do not save more, the investment necessary to ensure higher growth and more employment will only be funded by even greater recourse to foreign savings and a further build-up of foreign debt. We also need to save more because of the rapid ageing of the population which we face in the near future.

PARA.TAB: Even with a relatively robust recovery from the recession of the 1980s, saving will recover only modestly. In Dr FitzGerald's words, `It is structurally, not just cyclically, low.' Our underlying structural rate of national saving has fallen to around 18 per cent of GDP, five percentage points of GDP below the average of the past three decades.

The FitzGerald report found that, while both public and private saving have fallen, the major structural decline is in public sector saving. Dr FitzGerald advocated a national savings policy that would ensure the sustainability of strong ongoing growth rather than generating that growth. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Stronger national saving is an essential ingredient of any sustainable approach for pursuing ongoing healthy growth in the economy over the mid and late 1990s and beyond.

He suggested that a minimum requirement for a national saving strategy is to raise national savings structurally by several per cent of GDP. But the national saving goal should be higher—to restore the underlying national saving rate over the coming decade to around the average of the past three decades, 22 to 23 per cent of GDP—that is to lift it by about five per cent of GDP—and to lift the efficiency of our investment to best practice.

PARA.TAB: Dr FitzGerald said that a national saving strategy to carry out the task of reaching the goal set could comprise several broad elements. In the area of public saving, at each level of government, the general government sector should seek to move to a position of persistent significant surpluses on current transactions so as to generate positive saving and finance internally at least some government investment. The Commonwealth should seek to return its general government overall deficit to persistent surplus. Substantial reductions in outlays could be sought by moving all government service delivery programs to best practice efficiency. Cuts could also be achieved by re-ordering priorities and by means such as increased use of user charges. For Australia's public trading enterprises, the imperative is to ensure efficiency.

Finally, the strategy Dr FitzGerald recommended would include measures to address the eroding revenue base at all levels of government, including increased taxes and increased rates of taxes. The coalition does not support this as a part of a national saving strategy designed to increase national savings. To some extent, tax increases simply effect a transfer from private sector savings to the government.

To promote private saving, low and stable inflation have to be maintained and sustained healthy growth are basic to that objective. For households, which provide the bulk of private saving, it is necessary to settle the superannuation guarantee system and ensure optimal interaction with the age pension over the years ahead. Voluntary superannuation should be promoted by shifting the balance of tax concessions from compulsory employer contributions to voluntary individual contributions.

It is clear from this that in the budget the Government should have taken action structurally to reduce the deficit by cutting spending. The latest current account deficit of $2.252 billion is a consequence of the failure of the government to take action to address its out of control spending in previous budgets.

On budget night, the Treasurer announced that the government would be paying the tax cuts it promised in One Nation into employees' superannuation accounts. He claimed that in doing so the government was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . delivering them in a way that significantly improves national saving.

This is a claim that has subsequently been debunked decisively by the experts. Additional contributions will add six per cent of wages to the superannuation of people earning around average incomes. As a result, claims the Treasurer, by the year 2002 this will build on the nine per cent contribution from employers under the superannuation guarantee arrangements, lifting the superannuation savings for a person on around average earnings to a minimum of 15 per cent of their wages. Mr Willis claimed that the government's superannuation plan:
. . . will give Australia a comprehensive long-term private savings plan
and that—
for a couple on average earnings, now in their mid-30s, the Government's initiatives deliver retirement incomes 75 per cent higher than the age pension.
He continued:

Together with our earlier reforms, the initiatives are estimated to further increase national saving progressively by around 2 per cent of GDP per year by the end of the decade. When fully implemented, they will add 4 per cent of GDP per year to national saving. In today's values that means an increase in saving in the order of $18 billion per annum.
In addressing the National Press Club in Canberra on 10 May 1995, the Treasurer said of the government's superannuation plan:

It also means that over and above what [a person on average weekly earnings] would otherwise have been receiving through the pension and the superannuation guarantee, [they would have] a 22 per cent increase in their retirement income.

The government is in effect claiming that the benefits from its scheme will be: a substantial boost to national savings; higher incomes for retirees; and a more equitable distribution of superannuation benefits towards the lower paid.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, these claims are wrong. Employee superannuation contributions will of course raise national savings, but not by anything like three per cent of total earnings, according to an analysis of the budget by the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Many employees already contribute to their own superannuation plans, and will pay nothing more under the proposals. Not all employees will contribute. The three per cent payment is not universal, but will be introduced through awards and enterprise agreements. There will be no direct Commonwealth legislation making contributions compulsory. If employees are compelled, it will only be through changes in the terms and conditions affecting their award or enterprise agreements.

Also, when employees' superannuation increases, they tend to cut back on other forms of saving. The government estimates that for each dollar put into an employee's super fund, other private savings fall by around 30c. So employee contributions will raise national savings by an amount significantly less than three per cent of earnings.

Government contributions will not lift national savings at all. The increase in superannuation savings is offset by an equal reduction in government savings and, in fact, government contributions tend to reduce national savings.

In addition to the 30 per cent leakage from private savings, some 30 per cent of government contributions are also leaked through reductions in other savings. In the first year of maximum contributions, 2001-2002, the combination of employee and government payments will mean a net increase in new superannuation contributions of around $7.7 billion. With about $2.3 billion of that leaked away in reductions in private savings and a drop in the government's surplus of about $4.5 billion equivalent to contributions, the net gain to national savings will be around $900 million or 0.1 per cent of GDP—a far cry from the kinds of savings claimed in the budget papers.

The massive reported savings claimed by the government are not based on a comparison between national saving under the employee-government contributions scheme and national saving without the scheme. Instead, the budget papers misleadingly compare the effect of the proposals to what would happen if the government implemented the promised second tranche of the One Nation l-a-w law tax cuts. This is not the appropriate comparison to make. Without any corresponding cuts in government outlays, the net effect on national savings of the government's promised tax cuts would have been a loss of $5 billion. Compared to this, it is not surprising that even the very small but positive effect on national savings as a result of the government's superannuation proposals looks acceptable.

Even the government's own earnings projections present mixed evidence on employee benefits. From the year 2002, most employees' total super contributions will be at 15 per cent of earnings, 75 per cent higher than the previous plan for only a nine per cent employer contribution. As a result, lump sums on retirement will also be around 75 per cent higher.
But gross earnings are only part of the story. Since own-source income is higher, pension entitlements are reduced, and since income is higher, so is income tax.

According to the Treasury's estimates, under the new arrangements a male employee on average earnings who is retiring after 40 years of contributions at 15 per cent would receive an annuity worth $12,625 more than from the nine per cent employer contribution alone. But his pension entitlement would then fall by over $6,000 and his tax bill would increase by nearly $900. Of the total $12,625 increase in annuity, he is left with a net gain of $5,600. Leakage is even greater for the low paid, because the withdrawal of pension benefits has proportionally more effect. Both an employee on average weekly earnings and an employee on only 75 per cent of average earnings will be better off, in retirement, with the government and employee contributions than with employer contributions alone, but by only 22 per cent for the average income earner and 16 per cent for the lower paid worker.

While employees might gladly sacrifice three per cent of earnings over 40 years for the prospect of a 75 per cent higher income in retirement, the same might not be the case when those employees realise that the real gain in income is only 16 or 22 per cent. This is especially true of low income earners, who have least to gain in retirement and who are the most likely to miss their three per cent contributions.

If the government were serious about making a real contribution to national savings, it would make much greater inroads into its own underlying deficit and stop pretending that it will implement big tax cuts. If employees want to ensure a comfortable retirement, they should increase their own savings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The leading feature of last month's 1995-96 budget speech was a supposed surplus which budget papers reveal is actually a deficit. Furthermore, you do not have to be a professor of economics to understand that we are in big trouble if the deficit solution is to sell the government's stake in the Commonwealth Bank. It is like selling your car to pay the local authority rates for your home: next year, you will still have the annual rates to pay, but you will not own a motor car.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the average Australian has understood this very well, the government still trades on the fact that the general public does not necessarily appreciate the budgetary and employment implications of the April current account deficit figures. It is not my intention today to give an economics lecture but, instead, to sound a warning to Australians about an aspect of the impact of our chronic current account deficit that has never been dealt with in this parliament.

No matter what gloss this government puts on its performance and the disparagement it makes of the previous Liberal government, the figures tell the true story: our economic situation is infinitely worse than the one Labor inherited in 1983.

The feature of how federal Labor governments have responded to our chronic trading problems is to not address the source of the problem, but rather to steadily increase our foreign debt, with interest bills rising and more and more of our assets sold to foreigners. Should we then be surprised at the government selling the Commonwealth Bank in order to meet the budgetary challenge of the 12 months ahead? After all, we have been selling Australia to foreigners for years as Labor's so-called solution to our abysmal trading performance.

Having brought about a position where we must sell the farm in order to stay afloat as a nation, neither the Hawke Labor government nor the Keating Labor government has been at all fussy about either the identities of the buyers of Australian properties or the source of those purchasers' funds. Whilst foreign investment has always been a feature of the Australian economy—and a necessary feature of it—the 1980s saw our economy's reliance on foreign money reach a level unprecedented in our recent history.

Treasurer Keating's foreign investment policies are notable by the extent to which he relaxed previous requirements for Australian equity and transfer of assets from one foreigner to another. Of course, we badly needed foreign investment for development projects—to develop our tourism industry as a major source of foreign exchange and provider of jobs, for example. Investment in a number of other areas necessarily followed, as I am particularly aware, as a representative of the Gold Coast electorate since 1984. I welcome foreign investment in my electorate for the growth in jobs in the local economy that it has provided. However, I do not welcome the source of some of that investment. I am referring, in particular, to that foreign investment which has been nothing other than a money-laundering exercise by international criminals.

This is not news, of course. In fact, the most depressing aspect of how we have allowed trans-national crime organisations to get a foothold in this country is that it has been well publicised for several years now—yet the government has done nothing to try to combat it. On the contrary, it has loosened the restrictions on foreign investment and has never shown any real interest in tightening checks on where that money has come from.

If you press this issue with the government or government agencies, you are told that Australia has a system of law enforcement measures, through a range of government agencies, which should both identify the source of money and raise the barriers to dirty money being used to buy Australia. Unfortunately, the rhetoric is not matched by action, and there is no better example of this than the 1995-96 budget estimates.

The Australian Federal Police—the Commonwealth's principal law enforcement agency—will have its funds reduced from last year's expenditure of $235,671,000 to $184,844,000 for the forthcoming year, a reduction of $50,827,000. Austrac—the organisation charged with monitoring the movement of money into Australia—gets a modest increase of $1,463,000, from $7,466,000 to $8,929,000; and the National Crime Authority, a mere $136,000 more, an increase from $44,489,000 to $44,625,000. However, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence will suffer a significant cut from $5,324,000 to $4,184,000—a reduction of $1,140,000.

These figures show that the Commonwealth's principal law enforcement agencies have suffered a net reduction of $50,368,000. So much for the government's interest in monitoring, controlling, and/or reducing organised crime's movement into Australia.

The Attorney-General's budget reductions for associated organisations—the Australian Institute of Criminology, the Australian Securities Commission and the Criminology Research Council—show that the government has slashed funding for both its law enforcement agencies and associated bodies by a total of $54,368,000. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a comparison of 1994-95 estimated expenditure with 1995-96 appropriation for Commonwealth law enforcement and associated agencies which are part of the Attorney-General's Department.

Leave granted.
