TALK.START.PARA: —In last Thursday's adjournment debate I raised the matter of Gold Coast property owned by Masaru Takumi, a notorious Japanese organised crime boss. I first raised this issue in May 1993 and, following extensive newspaper publicity of the matter and several speeches by me in the House, Takumi's Australian visa was cancelled. Last Thursday I pointed out that he still co-owns with his wife the Australian based company Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd and his Surfers Paradise penthouse, despite being banned from entering Australia. I indicated that the mandatory Australian based director had changed since May 1993 and was now a Mr Edward Beaumont.

PARA.TAB: Last Saturday's Gold Coast Bulletin quoted an interview with Mr Beaumont, stating:
"I've never met Mr Takumi. All I know is what I read in the papers", said Mr Beaumont.
He said his Bundall accountancy firm, McConaghy and Company, had provided a service to Takumi Enterprises Pty Ltd since 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The article stated also:

PARA.TAB: Asked what he knew about Mr Takumi, Mr Beaumont replied: "I wouldn't know him from a bar of soap."
Mr Beaumont said his only contact with Mr Takumi was through an employee in Tokyo, and his company's only role was to handle the accounts of Takumi Enterprises each year.
He said Takumi Enterprises was not conducting business in Australia and police and government representatives had never questioned him about the company.
"Mr Takumi just owns this unit at Surfers Manhattan. I just make sure it's kept clean and do the accounts once a year," said Mr Beaumont.
"The unit is never used. Once a year his son-in-law comes here for a week to go to the casino."

SPEECH.PARA: I have no reason to believe that Mr Beaumont is anything other than an honest Australian doing his job. However, this is a perfect example of how naive we are in this country about the nature of organised crime.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, Takumi is doing business with an apparently reputable Australian without that person knowing anything about him. Apparently Mr Beaumont did not read—or does not remember reading—any of the extensive publicity given to Takumi in the local newspaper two years ago. Further, no Australian agency has acquainted Mr Beaumont with this fact, whether by interviewing him about his involvement with Takumi or otherwise.

The coup de grace in this is surely Mr Beaumont's dismissive comment that all this is really much ado about nothing because the penthouse is only used by Takumi's son-in-law when he also visits Jupiter's casino. It never ceases to amaze me how people can believe that crime figures and their associates would come to the Gold Coast apparently for the pleasure of a morning dip in the ocean off one of our many famous and beautiful beaches, with perhaps a round or two of golf, enjoying the fabulous Queensland weather after lunch, and then trip light-heartedly off to Jupiter's Casino for nothing more than an evening's relaxed enjoyment.

The Australian newspaper described the activities of one such happy traveller in an article published on 28 December 1993 under the heading `Japanese residents questioned in crusade against crime bosses'. That article said, in part:

Investigators attached to the State's Criminal Justice Commission have now received information that a high-ranking Yakuza member visited an Australian casino in August, with the member's associate bringing $700,000 into Australia that was used to buy gambling chips.

The next day the chips were allegedly cashed for the entire amount and the member and his associates left the casino. But sources said investigators found after examining AUSTRAC reports that $100,000 less than was brought in was declared when they left the country.

Sources say the associate of the Yakuza member has extensive criminal convictions including violence and an investigation has been launched on suspicion that the money might have been brought in for laundering purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt this pair looked like nothing more than another two happy travellers enjoying a casual evening at the casino.

PARA.TAB: To me, an alarming aspect of all this is that, for several years now, quite extensive publicity has been given in Australia to the shifting of large amounts of money offshore by Japanese organised crime. Since as long ago as the 1970s, when the Yakuza started their move into Hawaii, warnings have been being sounded world wide. We know that Australian law enforcement authorities were alerted by Japanese law bodies in the 1980s to the fact that Australia could be targeted in a similar fashion to Hawaii.

Further, there have been numerous media reports—newspaper, magazine and television—in Australia as well as overseas, on the shady money and the `grey men' who have apparently been moving money freely into Australia. Nevertheless, years down the track, Labor governments have taken no real action to protect our country from this scourge.

The first responsibility of any national government is to ensure the national security of the country which it is privileged to govern—whether that security may be breached through the force of arms of another nation, or through the more insidious, but no less concerning, way in which transnational organised crime appears to be moving into Australia virtually unfettered.

Wherever organised crime goes, in time the consequences become the same: the corruption of the agencies of law and order, be they police forces, politicians, lawyers or the courts. As this process takes place, the law enforcement agencies become less and less able and willing to carry out their proper duty in a democracy: that is, ensuring the rights and freedoms of the democracy's citizens.

The numerous commissions of inquiry into official corruption that have been held at state level in Australia in recent years have shown how organised crime can encroach on the rights of the ordinary law-abiding citizen. My concern, as a member of the national parliament, is that that encroachment is taking place today because the Australian government—this Keating government—is not putting the resources into law and order that it should to enable transnational organised crime to be effectively combated.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with all other members of the House of Representatives, I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1), and to have the chance—as we do every year—to reflect on a number of government programs, following the release of the government's budget for 1995-96.

PARA.TAB: What I find most frustrating about speeches in the budget debate is the degree to which a number of people—from both sides, I confess—come into either this Main Committee room or the chamber and generate a great deal of atmosphere which suggests that `We have got it right and they have got it wrong', or vice versa, depending on which side of the debate one is taking.

Sometimes I long—as you must, Mr Deputy Speaker—to rise and remind all members that everyone has a right to a point of view in either of the chambers, and that that point of view is entitled to be heard without intervention and without interruption, simply because this chamber is all about giving people opportunities to put points of view on behalf of their constituents.

None of us has a monopoly on what is right for the country. Each of us represents a mean figure of about 80,000 electors, who depend on us to be their voice in this parliament. Whether they voted for us or not is relatively unimportant, in terms of the appropriation debate. They are the people who expect us to represent what we see as a realistic point of view.

So I come into this debate, year in and year out, with a particular point of view—a point of view that I believe I am entitled to be heard on. I am confident—without being egotistical about this—that that general view is shared by the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown).

What I find most unhelpful in budget debates is not the fact that people disagree with what I am saying, but the fact that a view that is expressed by anyone is greeted with scorn and derision rather than with polite assessment.

Part of the problem we face as parliamentarians, particularly in an appropriation debate, is that, because the debate allows people to range over a broad width of opinion, people taking particular points of view are often being greeted by scorn and derision, rather than by objective analysis. And while that is a difficulty we all face, it tends in itself to further reduce the credibility of the parliament and the enthusiasm that people have for witnessing the debate, listening to it or, frankly, participating in it. It is fair to say, I think—and I do not intend to be unfair in my expression—that it is a characteristic that is generally enhanced by the style of the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I am not suggesting by that comment that the government has a monopoly on this. But the present Prime Minister's confrontationist style tends to enhance this level where we come into these debates, put a point of view and are greeted with scorn and derision, rather than by people who are prepared to first analyse what is being said.

So I want to say that I come into this debate a bit distressed by the fact that, over and over again, government members have suggested that the opposition was in some way coming into the budget from a point of view that suggested that it was committed to a goods and services tax. In spite of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) could not have done more to distance himself from that policy, government members still want to run the line that the opposition is in some way married to the concept of a goods and services tax.

The fact that the government runs that line becomes even more irritating when the government itself, in this budget, introduces something akin to a goods and services tax through the way it deals with the building industry. So opposition members find themselves very irritated by the fact that, having expressed an enthusiasm for disowning the goods and services tax, they are both branded with it and then expected to endorse legislation that introduces a broader tax base for the building industry.

Another area in which there seems to be perpetual confrontation between government and opposition is the whole question of industrial relations. I find it particularly galling to be branded with a party that is allegedly advocating a youth wage and allegedly advocating a $3-an-hour wage structure when all of this has been totally disowned by the opposition. This perception is further reinforced by the Prime Minister's constant reference to the opposition as people who do not know what it is like to represent and to work side by side with working people. The emphasis, particularly in the House of Representatives during this budget debate, on the enthusiasm of the opposition to be representing the battlers of Australia has been further eroded by the Prime Minister and those opposite who have wanted to pour scorn and derision on the opposition every time the word `battler' is mentioned.

Without in any sense claiming a monopoly on the capacity we have to speak for working people, I would like to say that all of us who represent electorates that have a broad profile of Australian people, and particularly those of us who represent rural electorates, know what it is to be speaking for working people. There are few people who are marked out as battlers as much as those employed on the land in Australia. You would know that, Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, from your own experience and your own involvement as a farmer. I think it is fair for the opposition to stand up and, while not claiming a monopoly on representing battlers, to claim to be speaking for those who, frankly, cannot live on their present remuneration. Far from the opposition seeking to reduce that remuneration through its industrial relations policy, the intention is quite the contrary. The intention is to allow them to have greater remuneration as productivity increases.

Now, what does this budget do for Australians and particularly for my constituency? There are certainly those in my constituency who, I must say, welcomed the fact that the government avoided the Industry Commission interim report which recommended a change in the tax status for the Australian wine industry. The government, obviously recognising that here is an industry facing real opportunity for export growth and for generating additional export income, has not heeded the interim report. It has, in fact, been responsible in the way it has dealt with that report. We, as a parliament, now face the challenge of waiting for what this particular committee of inquiry recommends in its final report and then responsibly dealing with it so as not in any way to thwart the export growth of this industry.

The government has taken a number of initiatives that, frankly, have been in Australia's interests. Government and opposition have mutually stood, for example, for the reduction in tariff walls and protection in order to make this a more competitive country. What we have seen, particularly as it appears that the drought now shows signs of breaking—in some areas, I concede; I said that it shows signs—and as the opportunity for rural productivity goes up, is that in fact this has mercifully coincided with rising commodity prices, particularly in the case of the wool industry, and to a lesser extent the grain industry, as the combined efforts of the government and the opposition, through the World Trade Organisation, have allowed us greater opportunity to keep out of the markets that are traditionally ours those who have produced subsidised grain.

So, in the wheat industry, the wool industry, the wine industry, the sugar industry, the dairy industry and even the beleaguered citrus industry, there are opportunities for export growth. I recognise that those opportunities exist because of the way in which the government has gone about its negotiations with tariffs, the GATT arrangements and now the World Trade Organisation over the last decade, but that does not alter the fact that the budget does not do what it could do to encourage productive Australians.

The budget claims to be balanced when the balance, as previous speakers have said, is largely the result of asset sales. In fact the budget claims that it is likely to bring in a surplus when that surplus is largely masked by the impact of those asset sales. In my view what the budget fails to do is reduce the tax burden currently being carried by Australians so that they are themselves encouraged to be more productive. As previous speakers have indicated, and I will simply refer to these figures briefly, the reality is that during the period of this government, while wages have risen in real terms by 90 per cent, the individual tax take has gone up by 136 per cent and the sales tax burden borne by Australians has gone up by 305 per cent.

Those opposite have said, `This additional revenue has allowed us effectively to develop social programs to improve the lifestyle in Australia,' but this additional revenue has also come at the expense of every productive Australian. The chasm that exists between government and opposition is such that we would say that productive Australians need to be encouraged to be more productive in order to relieve the debt and to provide a larger pie that can effectively be carved up to aid all Australians.

What we are facing right now is a situation in which our productivity has not gone up in sufficient measure to meet the demand of this increasing social wage. What the opposition stands for is not pruning the capacity of Australians to earn a real income but for improving their opportunity to be productive and to generate more export income for Australia.

As opposition members we are appalled at a budget that effectively leaves in place the debt. If you take away the asset sales the nation is still substantially in debt. We have in fact lost the opportunity to sell those assets again. There are members opposite who are clearly unhappy about the decision to sell the Commonwealth Bank. I cannot say that runs counter to the things that I as an opposition member believe in, but I can say that it represents an asset that the government has sold and not used of itself to generate additional productive income. It is this inconsistency between what the budget purports to deliver and what the budget effectively delivers that leaves the opposition so concerned about these appropriation bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) I would like to start with a well-known story from Aesop's fables. The story goes like this:

SPEECH.PARA: A shepherd's boy had gotten a roguish trick of crying; A wolf! A wolf! when there was no such matter, and fooling the country people with false alarms. He had been at this sport so many times in jest, that they would not believe him at last, when he was in earnest; and so the wolves broke in upon the flock, and worried the sheep without resistance.

The moral of this tale, which is age-old, is said to be that there are dangerous consequences of an improper and unseasonable fooling. The old moral observes that a common liar shall not be believed even when he speaks true.

PARA.TAB: Judicious lying has always been considered part of statecraft. According to that master political tactician, Nicolo Machiavelli, a leader must:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . know well how to disguise [faithlessness]. . . and to be a great pretender and dissembler; and men are so simple, and so subject to present necessities, that he who seeks to deceive will always find someone who will allow himself to be deceived.
I suggest it is the Australian people who have been monumentally deceived by the Keating government.

PARA.TAB: Let us examine a few of the government's grand statements. In the 1985 budget speech the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), said, `I've outlined the government's strategy for the new financial year. It's a strategy that builds upon our very significant success and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former government.' What happened? Within months Australia was in the middle of the infamous banana republic current account crisis. In the following July, the Australian dollar collapsed to less than 60c, the lowest level on record. Since Labor came into power, the Australian currency has in fact lost almost 40 per cent of its value.
In the 1987 budget speech the current Prime Minister told us:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the enormity of the trade difficulties we have faced, our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.

That fruit turned out to be more like poison ivy. Within two years Australia was experiencing the largest current account blow-out on record. In the 1988 budget the current Prime Minister promised, `The nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation. This is the one that brings home the bacon. Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.' What really happened? Over the following year net foreign debt rose by 22 per cent. In August 1988 the Prime Minister again declared, `Now we are well on our way back to prosperity.'

PARA.TAB: In the 1989 budget speech he promised, `As a result of the government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.' But by 1990 Australia had entered the worst recession in 60 years. Never one to be daunted for long by grim reality, the Prime Minister then declared, `This is a recession, a slow-down, Australia had to have.' Still, we were assured, `Nobody's going to get hurt; it's going to be a soft landing.' Some soft landing for the million unemployed or for the 700,000 Australians who are still today out of work. What we had had, according to the Prime Minister, was too much of a good thing. He said insightfully, in his usual elegant English, in January 1990, `Too much of a good thing can still be too much of a good thing. I mean, basically the glass is too full and the effervescence is spilling over the sides, and that effervescence is the current account and inflation.' He seemed to be confusing the Australian economy with the soluble Disprin, although the analogy is not far wrong because the economy has been heavily sedated by this government, as well as the truth.

But there is more. The current Prime Minister claimed at another press conference in the same period, `In three years there will be no government debt, domestic or external. It is an enormous claim that I can make on behalf of the government of Australia. I'd doubt there is any other OECD economy that will not have any bonds on issue at all.' The only thing the Prime Minister was right about, as usual, was that it was an enormous claim. It was also an utterly fraudulent claim, because the current account deficit now stands at $27 billion.

A little later, in February 1993, Prime Minister Keating announced, `I think Australia has already crossed the Rubicon. Exports are still going gang busters. I mean, it's been a revolution. This is a much more productive country. It's now enmeshed truly with the rest of the world economy as it never was before 1983.' The allusion to the Rubicon was a little classical for the member for Blaxland. Talking about squashing things with his fist or his boot when they prove recalcitrant or pesky is more his post-Weimar Republic style. The thing he omitted from this pronouncement was that, if exports were doing all right, imports were doing even better, more than cancelling out the effect of the exports on our trade balance.

The remark about being enmeshed with the world is, too, not so good as it might portend. Basically, what it means is that, while we are playing the trade game according to the rules of the level playing field, other nations are playing according to the rules of a bumpy, if not downright mountainous, playing field. When there is a lot of foreign debt because people are so taxed and incentives for saving have been taken away, we end up extremely enmeshed in the rest of the world and vulnerable to every ill wind that blows upon our shores.

In 1992, in the full flight of an election campaign, this Labor government promised tax cuts. These were to compete with what was offered by the coalition but Labor's tax cuts were advertised as all gain and no pain. In fact, as it has turned out, it would have been truthful to say that they would be all pain and no gain. Prime Minister Keating told us that he would deliver tax cuts in two rounds, costing about $3.5 billion each. There were impeccable reasons for reducing marginal tax rates which have succoured the bulk of Australian workers. To pay Australia's top rate of marginal income tax, which is almost 50 per cent in Australia, people only have to earn $35,000. In Japan, for example, people have to earn $250,000 to incur the top rate of tax. So the Prime Minister announced that new tax scales would be introduced in two stages on 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996. He said that the fundamental objectives of these tax scales were to reduce the marginal rate facing the great majority of the full-time work force, including those on medium and average wages, from 38 per cent to 30 per cent and to reduce the marginal tax rate for those earning up to $50,000 per year, including, for example, those who derive such income through overtime or shift loadings, from 46 per cent to 44 per cent.

The Prime Minister later declared in the face of criticism that tax cuts were pie in the sky: they are a promise; they are law, l-a-w law. Of course, the l-a-w law is more like a l-i-e lie as the shadow Treasurer has pointed out. The first round for people earning less than $700 a week took place but only by raising taxes by almost as much. Since the 1993 federal election, Prime Minister Keating has jacked up taxes by around $3 billion a year.

In the most recent budget, we have been told what we had always suspected, that the tax cuts for the bulk of the population have been relegated to the land of the never-never. They were never-never going to happen. They were a convenient fiction, the rabbit in the hat. We are now regaled with a new trick. This is called `super super on the never-never.' It does not start until July 1997, 18 months after the second round of tax cuts were due, and the government's full three per cent contribution, which is only for earners under $46,000 a year, does not come into effect until July 1999. But, of course, any real benefits of this total scheme do not come until the year 2042. This is government on the never-never. By then the member for Blaxland will either be dead or in a very expensive nursing home somewhere like Monte Carlo. As the shadow Treasurer said, it is all very surreal.

The super is being sold as very super, with the government telling the people on its pre-election road show that they will get golden handshakes of over $400,000 just like top executives. People are, of course, thrilled because they really do want to believe their government is doing the best for them. But, as super analysts are saying, if super funds yield a long-term yearly average of four per cent, which is realistic on past performance in this country, a 40-year participant would retire in 2042 with just over $153,000, which is not quite enough to buy an annuity equivalent to the current old age pension.

Why should we believe this government? On the basis of its past record, `super' super will never eventuate in the form which it is advertised. The likelihood is that the government contributions will never materialise. There will always be some good reason to resist honouring that pledge. Even the original pre-selection of the member for Blaxland is straight out of Machiavelli. It was doubtful that he would win pre-selection, and his mate, the current Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), drove off with the ballot boxes on the pillion of his motorbike. When he returned with them, it was found that the present member for Blaxland had the votes—he had the votes in the box. There is a pertinent passage, on which I wish to conclude, in Machiavelli's The Prince, which tells how a military commander, the crafty son of a potter, one morning assembled the people and the senate of Syracuse:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as if he had to discuss with them things relating to the republic, and at a given signal the soldiers killed all the senators and the richest of the people; these dead, he seized and held the princedom of that city without any civil commotion.

The talking up of a republic, as with everything else in this government's bandbox, is not what it seems. We should be prepared for more truths of the l-a-w law variety in the Prime Minister's statement this week. We will accept them at this country's peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On every occasion that I rise in this place I find there is cause for concern about this procedure. This afternoon I have two concerns. Firstly, I think it is totally inappropriate for the appropriation bills to be debated in this Main Committee. As far as I am concerned, there is nothing more important in the deliberations that affect Australians than the annual presentation of the general government direction, as outlined within the budget. Although there is continuity, as a result of the arrangements with the states, and in salaries, wages and in ongoing commitments at a federal level, the budget is the most important parameter by which the public at large can get some idea of just what the government is up to, where they are going to be called on to fund its services, and the way in which their own lives and economic and social conditions will be affected or prejudiced.

PARA.TAB: It is most inappropriate that this Main Committee should be the place where that document is discussed. It is even more so this afternoon, when there is a matter of prime importance going on in the main chamber. Yet this chamber continues: it is irrelevant. It is important that the people of Australia understand that under Labor, sadly, the parameters of parliamentary discussion and the importance of parliament are progressively being eroded. I do not agree with this trend.

I believe that this chamber should be adjourned, so that we can all go and participate in the debate in the main chamber. It is no use saying that members will not be able to participate in the appropriation debate unless they take the opportunity to speak now. The only reason that is so is through government maladministration, expressing exactly the same incompetence in matters of the administration of the parliament as in administering the country. It is really a farce that we are up here, a few of us talking in isolation, albeit that it is telecast within parliament. The parliament and the nature of our democracy are too important for the main chamber to be seen to be other than the place where we all should be, and where matters of prime importance should be discussed.

Having said that, I want to say a few things about the Appropriation Bill No. 1 1995-96 and a few things generally about government administration. The first thing that concerns me about the bill is that there seems to be a total lack of understanding by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) as to what is happening out there in rural Australia. I know that on other occasions I have spoken about the extent to which there has been a decline in the terms of trade affecting Australia's commodity producers. If one had a look at the Dresner commodity index one would see that, apart from the odd exception, prices are falling significantly. Indeed, only today we learnt of the collapse of sugar prices and the impact that this will have on the sugar industry.

Over the years that Labor has been in office, first under Prime Minister Hawke and now under Prime Minister Keating, there has been a tendency to look only to what are called the new industries, the so called `smart' industries, the elaborately transformed manufactures, or ETMs as they are known in the jargon of the people in trade. But they are not the only basis on which this country lives and survives. Indeed, were it not for our commodity exports, this country would be in an even worse financial state, and be indebted to an even greater degree than it is today.

It is not just an economic cost but a social and educational cost that this government ignores, and ignores at Australia's peril. I mentioned educational cost last in that trilogy but really it is in education that more and more I am seeing the consequences of the drought and the recession we had to have. The drought has certainly eroded the incomes of small business people and the family farmers. Farmers generally, and people in small communities, have the same right to the educational process as everybody else in this community. Indeed, in the rhetoric of these days, one rather expects that, unless you are a minority, and a vocal one at that, you have no chance of attracting government's attention.

Sadly, there are many people who are deprived of an ordinary educational opportunity simply because of the drought and economic recession. It is no use the government saying, `We have modified the conditions of our aid program for students so that those who have capital but no income are not disadvantaged.' It is true that there have been modifications within the aid to students, but they do not address the fundamentals of those who are forced to leave their education and go back to run the farm; they do not address the fundamentals of those who find they cannot stay on at university or receive a tertiary or even a secondary education simply because they know they have got to go out into the work force to try to keep the family going. That is happening in far too many cases.

It has always been the case in this country that those who live in remote areas are to a greater degree disadvantaged more than those in the closer areas. But today both share in the disadvantages of the educational system as it affects people through the assistance that the government provides and generally in the opportunities they have for equality with those in the city. It applies as much as anything from the long since introduced Dawkins reduction in assistance for residential accommodation in universities. If you live a long way from a university, you cannot go and get education on the same basis as everybody else, and yet the assistance that used to be provided for halls of residence has been removed and there is a fundamental problem in the inequalities of education.

To highlight that problem, I have looked at some figures that the manufacturers have produced. When we look at the extent to which they see things changing, we note that they are in a not much different position, particularly the small business people, who really are the life blood of this country. The Prime Minister the other day dismissed them as never having had it so good. If anything, that statement yet again underlined the trauma that there is for people out there totally ignored by the principal ministers of this government.

In manufacturing we have real problems because, quite contrary to the Prime Minister's statement, according to a survey by the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales and a State Bank of New South Wales quarterly survey, business conditions, sales and profitability have fallen to levels that have not been seen since March 1993. When we look through the performance generally and we see why that is so, we find that, just as in primary industry, to quote from that survey:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary factors inhibiting small manufacturers from investing are government taxes and charges and the rise in interest rates.

I wanted to set that climate because there seems at the moment to be a bit of a tendency to suggest that interest rates have now peaked and are going to fall. I noticed a particularly optimistic statement from the National Farmers Federation the other day suggesting that was so. I do not know whether it has any better reason than anybody else for making a suggestion of that character but there have already been three interest rate increases. There has already been an increased burden on those who are self-employed, the family farmers and the small business sector, and they are now being saddled with a plethora of additional charges that this budget produces.

PARA.TAB: The budget comes on top of those three increased interest rates. Even if interest rates fall, nobody is suggesting that they will go back to where they were. With our overseas debt as it is and with our chronic adverse balance of payments deficit, there is certainly no suggestion that we are going to get our economy to a position where once again we might be able to expect that our interest rates will be competitive with the United States or with any of those other OECD countries against whom we are compared and with whom we obviously always need to compete.

It is my worry that this budget has done nothing for small business and done nothing for the family farmer. It has really only yet again reasserted the fact that they are the neglected segment of the Australian community. When we look at the changes in this budget, we see that their position is further aggravated. The Medicare levy has increased—I will come back to health if I get time—and there are sales tax increases on motor vehicles. The tax on building materials really introduces a GST. It is no use the government saying, `But you were going to introduce a 15 per cent GST'—I wish we could have a debate on that—because, significantly, we were going to change Australia's tax system fundamentally.

My concern with the GST was not with its ingredients but with the fact that it was presented far too rigidly and it was not put forward as being the fundamental way by which we could get a total change in Australia's tax structure. Unless we do that, we are going to be saddled even more with the sorts of increments that this budget represents—sales tax increases, company tax increases, increases that affect, either directly or indirectly, everybody in the community. One of the taxes, that on light fuel, has particular relevance to the rhetoric we have heard from the Prime Minister over the weekend and today about the standard gauge link between Melbourne and Adelaide. I will return to that in a moment.

Small businesses and family farmers, like everybody else, are going to pay more sales tax. As a result of the increase in company tax, they will pay in another way for that increase. They are going to pay more in their Medicare levy, and as of 1 July they will have yet another sales tax increase. In the parameter of operating Australia, and as we go into an election, it is quite critical that people understand that the important component of Labor, in its budget, in its political utterance, is that it will care for its own and to hell with the rest of them. Sadly, those who are the most important element in getting Australia moving again happen to be in the rest of them. It is that particular group for whom I feel at the moment: there is absolutely no hope for them under a Labor government. There is one reason why people out there ought to understand why Labor is long past the stage of being able to contribute to Australia's advancement and that is because it is prepared to neglect that important, vital element of the Australian economy.

I now want to look at the budget deficit because this is another part of its presentation that I am concerned with. There is no doubt that, if the government had been able to achieve that $700 million surplus that it claims, it would have been a remarkable achievement. I have looked through to try to find how it was made up. I was interested to hear that a few people have even tried to find out where the figures were and, of course, they are not there. I am interested in the fact that Bain and Co. have disaggregated and extracted a number of one-off factors. It has shown that the real deficit is $12.5 billion. Let me just identify those because I think that is another part of the way in which this government operates. It ignores elements important to the community and is prepared to deceive people into believing that, in some way, things are different from what they really are. That is what the debate is about in the main chamber at the moment.

The advertised surplus is $0.7 billion. Let us take off the asset sales which have been extensively canvassed during this appropriation debate. The government has them down at $5.4 billion, which is a totally unrealistic figure in the circumstances. The Qantas sale is going on at the moment but it is a distortion of reality to look at Qantas other than as an asset which is not being presented in its true light. There are all sorts of implications from the deal done with New Zealand to prevent the introduction of Air New Zealand into Australia, as was originally agreed, to the way in which Qantas services have been reduced and the way in which funds are not being provided to allow the purchase of new aircraft to take advantage of the present surge in aircraft passenger traffic. I think it is quite ridiculous to look at Qantas as being worth the money that the government is putting on it. But, in any event, it has been presented for the third time in this budget as an asset sale. For the government to expect to get $5.4 billion out of it is absolutely farcical. Repayment of state government debt is $1.8—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 5.35 p.m. to 5.47 p.m.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—A quorum not being present through the absence of a government member, the sitting is suspended.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my remarks I have tried to canvass the fact that the budget does nothing for rural Australia or small business. I have regretted the fact that the recession still continues there, that it has a social fallout that is even greater than the economic one, and that the budget does nothing towards it. I was identifying the sham that the budget surplus in fact represents.

PARA.TAB: As we adjourned, I was quoting from Bain and Co. which showed the items which constitute the $12.5 billion real deficit. I have mentioned the asset sales of $5.4 billion. Bain and Co. included the repayment of state government debt at $1.8 billion. In fact, this is only a bookkeeping entry. Public enterprise superannuation is down, at $1 billion, which again is a bookkeeping entry. Reserve Bank dividends certainly is a book entry and it includes, of course, an increase in the interest being charged to the trading banks on unutilised funds. That goes up by—I think—half a billion dollars. The Reserve Bank dividends are $2.1 billion. There are government enterprise dividends of $1.3 billion and company tax advance payments are $1.6 billion. If we exclude all of those—as probably we should—we finish with a deficit of $12.5 billion, which is the real position of this budget. So all the rhetoric about having a surplus is no more than that.

Just before concluding, I want to identify one of the areas where the sham of the budget is best portrayed. As the minister who finally managed to get the trans-Australian standard gauge line in place, I feel quite strongly about some of the rhetoric over the course of this weekend on the very commendable link of the standard gauge between Adelaide and Melbourne. Let there be no doubt that the late Malcolm Summers, who was then secretary to the Department of Shipping and Transport, would be delighted to know that, so long after, one of those dreams that he had and that I shared for a link around Australia has finally been concluded. For all that I disagree with the Prime Minister on many issues, he has said that conflicts between state rail authorities have really been the impediment.

We need to look at the nature of the $184 million payment and at some of the implications that there are in this budget. When I look through the budget papers, I notice that one item is the increase in excise on light fuel oils. Honourable members will remember, in Budget Paper No. 1, page 416, the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Legislative amendments will be introduced in the budget sittings to change the definition of fuel oil to exclude so-called light fuel oils which are, in fact, industrial diesel fuels. This measure will begin from 1 July and result in these fuels being excised at the diesel rate.

You might well say that those people who have been trying to change from the excisable diesel fuel to light fuel oils deserve to pay the price, but there is a cost. Part of the cost is represented in the change from distillate to light fuel oil that state rail authorities and the Australian National Rail Corporation have made with their own locomotives. One of the reasons why the rail authorities have made this change is that this government has been extracting approximately the amount that standard gauge rail costs year by year, by way of diesel fuel excise, from the railways! The government has been doing so without in any way contributing to building up standard gauge railways.

PARA.TAB: The weekend farce occurred because the government is, by way of diesel fuel excise, year by year taking the amount that standard gauge connection costs. I am all in favour of it being done, but I wish to goodness the government would be honest. Indeed, if honourable members read the March 1990 paper by the Interstate Commission `Road use charges and vehicle registration: A national scheme', volume 1, at page 180, they will find a comment that this government should have in mind. In relation to diesel use by rail, the commission states:

SPEECH.PARA: Such fuel should be regarded as an input to production rather than as an end consumption and hence should not be taxed for general revenue purposes. Rail operations do impose externalities that would be inappropriately recovered through fuel excise duty.
The Interstate Commission is not the only agency to pursue this line of argument. In its report on rail, the Industry Commission states:

As a general principle, the commission argues against levying any such tax on fuel to be used as an intermediate input. Consistent with this, the commission is of the view that railways should not be required to pay excise on diesel used for freight purposes.

That admonition was published in 1990. Although I have, unfortunately, been able to get figures only for the period when the actual amount taken from the railways by the Commonwealth by way of diesel fuel excise was $118 million, from the papers I have been able to obtain, I understand that, with inflation and with changes in diesel fuel excise, the amount is now closer to between $180 million and $200 million per year. The cost of the standardised link between Adelaide and Melbourne is $184 million, and, year by the year, the Commonwealth is taking, by way of diesel fuel excise, this amount of money. This is totally unjustified, and, of course, it is against what the Interstate Commission says.

PARA.TAB: This budget is a sham and a farce. This budget ignores the important elements of Australian society which, sadly, are still languishing in recession. This is a budget which does not entitle the government to go to the people and to say that Australia is now on the road to recovery. This is a budget which, sadly, is increasing the impost on ordinary Australians; the battlers about whom we have heard so much in the last few days. It is the battlers who suffer at the hands of this Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled at the constraining of this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96. One has only to look on the other side of the chamber to see the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) as the only one representing the government—although the number has now been doubled by the presence of the honourable member for Parramatta, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Elliott). It is an absolute scandal that this most important debate has been constrained the way it has. The speaking list is a great long list of opposition speakers, but how many do we have from the government—a big zero so far.
—They have got nothing to say.
—They have got nothing to say, because this budget is—
—I think they know it's full of lies.

—Well, first of all, the budget is a fraudulent budget; secondly, it is a fudge-it budget; and, thirdly and most importantly, it is a rubbery budget. It is a rubbery budget because the government is indulging in what I would term arithmetic gymnastics. One needs to look no further than the way it calculates the so-called surplus to understand what I mean. I will come back to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: It is not just the opposition that is criticising this budget. There is a wide range of people from a wide range of community organisations who are criticising the budget for what it says. I just quote from one or two of those. In the area of jobs the president of ACOSS, Robert Fitzgerald, said:

SPEECH.PARA: But what the budget won't do is break the cycle of poverty or address the issues of inequality.
He went on to say:

While we acknowledge the government's commitment to maintaining Working Nation's outcomes, one has to seriously question whether they can be delivered, given these massive cuts. I think that the public has to be very cautious about accepting that line.
That is the first point, in the areas of jobs. In the area of indigenous peoples, the chair of ATSIC, Lois O'Donoghue, has said:

By transferring responsibility for Aboriginal health away from ATSIC the states and territories will see this as a Commonwealth responsibility and not their responsibility. The transfer is certainly an abrogation of, I guess, what ATSIC was set up for, to enable indigenous Australians to make decisions about their lives. To mainstream functions doesn't give us confidence that the government is serious about reconciliation.
That is point 2. In relation to business, Ian Spicer, of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said:
It is a high-spending, high-taxing budget and overall business will be very disappointed. The government have squibbed on the hard task of cutting expenditure.
Paul Barrett, the executive director of the Business Council of Australia, said:
The increased revenue measures of $2.4 billion fall primarily on business and are a disguised attack on the present and future incomes of ordinary Australians.
In the area of health, the new president of the Australian Medical Association said:
We welcome the public health initiatives in this budget such as immunisation strategy, the focus on youth suicide—
both of which the opposition would support—

but we really feel that these are bits of tinsel on top of a rotten Christmas tree. The budget does nothing to address the basic structural problems in health care financing. In particular, we point to the Medicare levy rise, the absence of any initiatives to increase private health insurance membership . . .
So it is not just the opposition that is speaking, but a wide range of those in the community in general.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the arithmetic gymnastics and the so-called surplus. That surplus is highly dependent upon asset sales. As my colleague the shadow minister for finance, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), has pointed out on a number of occasions since that budget was brought down, one has only to look at the government's record in terms of asset sales to see exactly where it is not heading. In 1990-91 the asset sales estimate was $1,000 million. What has been achieved—$161.7 million. In 1991-92, where the government's estimate was $625 million, it achieved less than 50 per cent of that—$301.8 million. In 1992-93 it estimated $1,600 million and achieved $801 million. In 1993-94, which is the only year when the government actually achieved, it predicted $2,400 million and achieved $2,470 million. In 1994-95, the current financial year, $2,450 million is what was estimated. What has been achieved so far—$55 million. What does the government predict in 1995-96? Wait for it: $5,350 million. With that sort of record how could one possibly believe the government?

Here is a little example. Table 1 is to do with outlays by function. In the defence area for 1995-96, the budget we are debating, there will be an outlay of $9.992 billion for defence. That compares to the public debt interest outlays of $10.077 billion. So, as my colleague the shadow minister for defence science and personnel pointed out, the defence of our nation is subsumed by public debt interest payments. I think that is a very salient point to recognise.

But that is not where it finishes. The government claims that it has achieved a surplus by expenditure restraint. The simple fact is that real outlays, excluding asset sales, are projected to grow by 1.7 per cent in 1995-96. Revenue is expected to grow 8.9 per cent in the financial year. In the last 20 years the only occasions on which revenue growth has been higher than this were in 1973-74, the first Whitlam budget, and the second Keating budget, of 1984-85. Those are two salient features that people seem to skirt around.

The other point, I suppose, is the current account deficit. The current account deficit is stuck at $27 billion and that, of course, will impact on interest rates. We will wait and see where that heads, bearing in mind that in the last financial year the government predicted, what, a $14 billion deficit—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was $18 billion.

—And revised it up to $27 billion. So, once again, can we believe it? And today net foreign debt is $167 billion, a 700 per cent increase since it first came in in 1983. So who really can believe this government?

PARA.TAB: Turning to the specifics of the budget, three or four years ago, in the depths of the recession, the building industry was the only thing that kept my area out of the depths of that recession. It was a relatively buoyant housing industry. Over the last five or six months, with interest rate pressures, that has disappeared. I think it is all said in letters I got from a lot of people over the last few days, and I quote from one of them:

SPEECH.PARA: We are some of this country's troubled and overtaxed small business people, carpenters, builders, cabinet-makers, joiners and all those associated with the home construction industry. This government is totally unaware of the real economic climate that is causing despair and total ruin of many business. The 12 per cent sales tax on all cupboard work involved on all building sites is surely the death knell to many of our struggling workshops. Not only does this raise the cost of homes by thousands overall, not the $400 as is suggested, but now gives the backyarder another 12 per cent advantage. We cannot see sound management in the idea of sending businesses to the wall, placing scores of workers on the dole queues. We are asking you to go to bat for us, our representative, to halt this madness and to restore some sanity in this insane tax mad government. Please give us your highest priority as workshops are closing almost by the week in our area.

And it finished with a plaintive `Help. Yours desperately'. We have made it very clear in the last couple of weeks that the federal coalition, the opposition, will indeed be opposing all of these tax increases.

PARA.TAB: In the few moments that I have got left in this debate, in the area of defence, as a result of question No. 1976, I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch) for their response in relation to the Voyager claims, but I have to point out that I hope that those Voyager claims will be settled very quickly.

There is one other area I want to mention, the area of health research. I will be saying a little more in a later debate on this, but in particular I want to draw to the attention of the Main Committee the unfortunate situation of the sufferers of chronic fatigue syndrome.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: 6.07 p.m.)—The departments that we are going to consider briefly this evening are the departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Finance and Treasury. We are going to consider the Advance to the Minister for Finance and the provisions for running costs and borrowings for those departments. In the earlier days of the parliament, this was a debate of great analytical ability where the management and the detail of the appropriations were considered effectively by the parliament. What is happening today is a sham. I do not think that there has been a government in Australia's history that has more denigrated the role of the parliament than the current government. Where is the capacity to analyse and to look at detail when we have a five-minute speech limit and we are on a whip? It has never before happened this way. I think that the Australian Labor Party—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I will get around to them, do not worry, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to deal with the departments broadly and point out to the parliament how the government has failed in these great departments. They used to be prime departments, departments of great prestige and eminence but the whole process has been despicably politicised. One has only got to look at a Labour Treasurer: Roger Douglas from New Zealand paid out on the Australian Labor Party for failing the workers. Roger Douglas says that nothing is more despicable than a Labor Party that has failed to take action on economic growth, unemployment, inflation, fiscal and balance of payment measures because it is the party that has worked harder to pull down the battler than anybody else.

PARA.TAB: Let me quote from Labor's policy concerning tax relief for pensioners. Let me read from the Labor Party policy of 1993. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's commitment to removing all age pensions from the tax free system in 1995 will benefit pensioners paid at the part rate as well as providing some assistance to retirees with incomes beyond the pension cut-out point.
This was an ALP document in 1993. It was a lie. Labor did not carry it out; it had no intention of carrying it out. The Australian Labor Party lied.

PARA.TAB: What about the improvement of Medicare through use of private beds? Here is a Keating promise, a prime ministerial promise—we know how valuable they are:

SPEECH.PARA: We will open Medicare up to the private hospital system so that it can purchase an estimated 10,000 private hospital beds per year for people on waiting lists.
It was a lie. It never happened. What about the promise to match Christmas appeal funds? On 6 December 1992, the Prime Minister said:
So, let me say to you, Laurie—
my friend, Laurie; yes, my friend, Laurie—

that for every dollar that the voluntary agencies like St Vincent de Paul, the Smith Family, the Salvation Army, collect for material assistance, the Commonwealth will match for the Christmas appeals.
This was never done; it was a blatant lie. It was pure vote catching. There was the use of superannuation for housing. What about this promise at the policy launch? It stated:
Labor will permit part of the deposit on owner-occupied dwellings to be funded from the home buyer's superannuation account.

This was a lie. It was never done. What an incredible waste Labor has been to the battlers it claims to represent. What about the self-repairing budget of John Dawkins? This is really incredible. On 28 February 1993, John Dawkins said:
As the economy picks up then the federal budget will be repaired along with it. Treasury estimates usually have underestimated the consequences of a pick-up on the budget.

A self-repairing budget—who would have thought it! Just to make sure that we do not leave the individual members of the party to one side, I have some copies of campaign pamphlets. There is one from the current member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) with the statements that he made, and some from somebody else. I have pages of these promises these people made and have never kept—not one of them. They have not kept one of these promises and they have made statements about the goods and services tax which makes the Keating sales tax look pale. Man, you could be describing it; these words could be taken and applied to the 1995 Keating budget. All of the exaggerations and lies used about the goods and services tax could be used to describe the Keating sales tax. The Keating sales tax is with us and the people are going to suffer because there is no compensation, there is no reduction in taxation, there is no benefit flowing through to the transportation systems of Australia, as committed by John Hewson.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure for me to be here on 2 1/2 minutes notice. I just wanted to say a couple of very quick things related to the education portfolio.

—This is good, because I have leaflet after leaflet here by Labor Party members. Let me read out your campaign stuff and the lies told to the Australian people and the Australian parliament by Australian Labor Party members coming up to the last election. None of their promises have been fulfilled. Let me go on reading from this list, because it is a great list. I have dealt with superannuation. The next is the relief for pensioners, which was a campaign policy commitment: not delivered. Improvement of Medicare through use of private beds: not delivered. It was a blatant lie. A promise to match the Christmas appealathon: another lie—never delivered. What about the use of superannuation funds for housing? That was another lie—never delivered.

PARA.TAB: The self-repairing budget—everything was going to get right as long as you trusted the Labor Party and left it alone. There were the One Nation tax cuts. They said, `Let me tell you something I think you might have to know. They have been legislated. They are not promises. They are l-a-w law.' And that was the tax cuts. In one of the brochures published by Labor Party members prior to the last election, we have people saying how they can trust Labor because Labor will deliver on their tax cuts.

An ad I have here is recognisable by its quality as a Labor Party ad. According to this ad, the ACTU-Labor deal says that the two later pay rises will only be available if government job creation targets are reached. `I believe the targets are reasonable,' Anna Booth said, `Union members will be able to go for all three pay rises.' All three pay rises, all three tax cuts: l-a-w law. How were they duded? How can Labor party members face their branch members when they have duded ACTU members into supporting your promises by going into advertising and saying that they believed you would deliver your promises? I say to Labor members: you won't deliver your promises; you have not delivered your promises. Mr Chairman, I think that the committee is ready to vote on this matter and bring the government down. They deserve to be thrown out of office. They are so inattentive, they are talking amongst themselves, and they cannot even agree. What an incredible sight this is! There is a big debate about who is going to reply. Suddenly they have decided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond briefly to a few of the matters raised by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I note at the outset that he made no contribution at all, in terms of the actual appropriation for the four departments that we are discussing here. First of all, there has been agreement reached between the government and the opposition to facilitate the discussion process through each of the areas of appropriation that are outlined here. The member for Mitchell spent the first couple of minutes attacking the process, and the last three minutes in talking about what happened in the last election campaign. He did not even come close to talking about the actual appropriations that we are dealing with.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular matters that were raised relating to pensions and promises, there are a few things that are worth noting. First of all, the government made a commitment that it was going to keep pensions about 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. That commitment has been honoured in full. Indeed, pensions today stand at something like 25.2 to 25.3 per cent of average weekly earnings.

We made other commitments in respect of part-rate pensioners, in that we would take steps to ensure that all part-rate pensioners received the full fringe benefits. The situation is confirmed in this budget: all part-rate pensioners, even with a dollar of pension, receive the full fringe benefit, including the health card and all of the facilities that go with the health card. Compare that to the previous government—which the member for Mitchell was part of—where pensions fell to about 22 per cent of average weekly earnings.

The member for Mitchell referred to the appeal funds commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in 1992, which was designed to directly assist groups that had their key fund raising in the period leading up to Christmas. These charity groups were obviously feeling the strain, because of the impact of demands made by many welfare groups at that time, due to the recession. The government not only met that commitment in full, in fact, the appropriations at that time carried an expansion of the money to match additional funds that were carried over past the December 1992 period, as some of the charities came forward with acquittals in early 1993. My recollection is that this meant an additional allocation on the part of the Commonwealth in the tens of millions, although I cannot recall the exact figure. The member for Mitchell is quite wrong in the assertion he made in that regard.

The government has made clear its ongoing commitment to Medicare. It has spelt out in the appropriations its strong commitment to the maintenance of Medicare, and its strong commitment to the public health system. That has been confirmed in successive budgets since that time.

As to the particular appropriations that we are dealing with here, the budget papers make clear that the government is committed to ensuring that the area of running costs is dealt with as firmly as is possible. There are further stringencies placed on running costs in this particular budget, in respect to the appropriations for the other agencies that are outlined in this first grouping. The fact that the member for Mitchell had nothing to contribute by way of any criticism of those measures suggests that they should be supported by the committee. I commend them to the chamber.
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) refer to the crowd opposite, who were at us in 1993 about the GST. We are going to hound the government about the `KST'—Keating's sales tax, particularly `KST' in the building industry.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) knows that the KST is already impacting on the building industry in south-east Queensland. In my region, as I said before, we had a buoyant housing industry until six or seven months ago. The impact of the interest rate pressures was just starting to feed through and now, on top of that, we have the 12 per cent building tax. My office has received a lot of correspondence and a lot of telephone calls about this tax in the last few days.

The government's situation is indefensible. On the one hand the government criticises the opposition about the GST, while on the other hand it is open to justifiable criticism for imposing the building tax. It is about revenue. It is about nothing else. The government knows that. The Keating government has just king-hit the building industry in south-east Queensland. I would be interested to hear the response from those opposite on that particular point.

In the area of health, I referred earlier to chronic fatigue syndrome. I am delighted that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) is sitting opposite. I hope he will take my comments on board—and perhaps the department is already doing so. Everybody is aware of chronic fatigue syndrome, but nobody wants to own that particular condition.

Unfortunately, the whole debate is being complicated by a lack of detailed knowledge of the nature of chronic fatigue syndrome. On the research effort that is going into that, I would be interested to hear from the parliamentary secretary, in response to the budgetary allocation, as to what degree the National Health and Medical Research Council is addressing CFS or ME, and perhaps MND—motor neurone disease—as well. What is the NHMRC doing in those areas? I ask that question not only as the federal member for Groom, but also as the patron of the local branches of the ME, CFS and MND associations. I would be interested to hear what the parliamentary secretary has to say on that. In particular, I would like to hear about the impact of that condition in the disability area.

I know of a particular case. We do not have time to go into the detail of it now, but I will raise it separately in another debate. It is a very desperate case of a lady who has been denied a disability support pension simply because of the question marks over the nature of CFS and the continuing argument in medical circles about whether or not it is a valid condition. I am not competent to make a judgment on that, but the parliamentary secretary might say something about that when he speaks.

Finally in the health area, I reinforce for the benefit of those opposite what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said as recently as yesterday about health services. He said that when this coalition is in government there will be no change to Medicare or to bulk-billing, but there certainly will be some initiatives to lift the game in terms of private health insurance schemes. I cannot say, nor will I say, anything more at this stage, other than to invite the parliamentary secretary to respond to some of those points.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of housing and regional development, I am sure the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) would acknowledge the amount of money that has been put into south-east Queensland, particularly through the better cities program and also the projected moneys that will go there, which are of the order of $200 million to $300 million.

PARA.TAB: Major projects in that area are the Gold Coast rail link plus the urban transport link. Those projects involve an examination of the whole notion of housing development and areas related to that. We are all looking at that through the urban review. The local governments are also looking to streamline their planning processes and they are working upon ways to operate in a more realistic way.

I just say to the honourable member for Groom that regional development is very definitely about local leadership. McKinsey showed that, as did Kelty and Lindsay Fox, who pointed out that, where regions are growing, where regions are developing, they have local leadership. I would urge the honourable member for Groom to be involved in the processes of regional development, to address those issues of housing, to address the urban reviews that are occurring, to address the lifestyle issues, be they in terms of greening or of waste management. I know that the honourable member for Groom and I need more water to manage, given that we are in areas where there is severe drought, very strict drought, but I think this budget offers an opportunity for local government and local regions to be major players in all the processes of government and to address these national agenda issues.

They are issues of planning, issues of the way in which people live—be they housing or public transport or infrastructures and local infrastructures—that need to be moved along. Contrary, I suggest, to the views of the honourable member for Groom, housing within that south-east corner has developed but there has also been an oversupply. I think everybody would recognise, certainly in terms of home units or apartments and so on, the oversupply which exists between the Gold Coast and southern Brisbane and up through to the Toowoomba area. That is one of the problems that people are having and trying to blame on a whole range of other problems—a basic lack of planning in the nature of housing that people actually want and the kind of housing that people actually want, and along with that go the necessary infrastructures.

They are the issues that are generally addressed in this housing and regional development budget. I know that the opposition finds it very difficult to find anything adverse to say about this. Who can speak up and say that we should not have $487 million in terms of the better cities program, decried it was by some people in the opposition from the very first? Having seen the program now actually in action and having seen it operate, people recognise that in very poor areas, in very badly planned areas, the kind of planning and the kind of change in lifestyle which have occurred through the better cities processes are being moved along.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly helps the battlers.

—It does indeed. Nobody can decry the fact that we have got a billion dollars which goes to local government to pursue a whole range of issues. I know that the opposition finds it very difficult to think that the poor have actually got an education, got a house and so on. Isn't it terrible that some of the battlers have actually grown away from the lino on the floor, the wood stove and the toilet down the back? Let us forget it—that is the attitude. Opposition members fasten on the $3.3 billion for this portfolio. Isn't it terrible! Isn't that what Australia is supposed to be about? Opposition members do not like it a bit. Worse than that, they do not like the fact that some of us have actually had an education. What a shame! They should have kept us down, as those people over 45 in Queensland were who never even went to high school, let alone gaining a university education. So they should not tell us anything. One of the impediments to regional development in that south-east corner of Queensland is the lack of skills and the lack of education of people.
—Most of them vote National anyway.

—No, they do not; they are voting Labor and they will vote for me! The whole issue of community housing is addressed within this budget by a recognition that people live in houses, in communities, and that they need a whole range of services and infrastructures that go with this. I know that members of the opposition can find nothing in this to decry and so they draw red herrings and run around and say, `Isn't it terrible—the end of civilisation as we know it.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96, I want to say a few words on human services and health. Let me begin by commending the government for the expenditures in this area and, indeed, in housing and regional development and all the other main social areas of the government. If one looks at the social justice statement which was supplied with the budget one finds a comprehensive statement of all the social programs of the government which were very important in the further promotion of social justice.

PARA.TAB: These terms `social justice' and `social wage' are very important because, as we saw in the House earlier today, there was a debate about a social wage. It was very interesting that in that debate there was an allegation by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that he had been misquoted. But in the speech that he gave on that debate, not once did he ever talk about the social wage. Not once did he talk about what the social wage means. Not once did he use the term `social justice'.

We hear from members of the opposition that suddenly they have discovered the battlers. Supposedly they have suddenly discovered what they call `the battlers' in Australian society. Yet these people do not even understand the basic terms involved—like social wage, like social justice. They have got no social justice philosophy and have never had one. I would like members of the opposition to tell me one single writer, one person who supports their party, who has ever written about or discussed the questions of social justice or a social wage. Never! Then they get up and try to talk about battlers.
Let me refer in particular to this area of human services and health. Yesterday we had the Leader of the Opposition saying finally, after five election losses—

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming up six.

—And coming up six, probably. But after five election losses, after we appealed to the opposition years and years ago to get behind Medicare, to support Medicare, to sustain Medicare, what did it do? Every election, `We're getting rid of Medicare.' Every election, `We're going to dismantle Medicare.' Then what happened? At the last election the Australian people said, `We want Medicare.' Finally, as a result of that, they decided, belatedly—not in their hearts, not because they have understood something about social justice—to tell us, `Oh, well, now we want Medicare.' After all those years!

PARA.TAB: The Australian people certainly want that fundamental program of Medicare but we in the government are not just committed to the program of Medicare, we are committed to improving health services in every direction. Look at all of the issues in this budget. There are all of the new arrangements for health and medical research; the new arrangements in terms of children's services; the new arrangements in terms of disability services and for aged care; and this huge program for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health.

All of those very important programs are directed towards achieving fundamental social justice for our people, which include the most disadvantaged in our community, such as the people who suffer from disability and the people who suffer because they have been disadvantaged, such as our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There is a new program for people of non-English speaking background. There is a whole set of programs to assist in residential care and community care for the aged. All of those programs are specific programs, worked out, funded, costed, in order to achieve concrete outcomes for those Australians who are in a disadvantaged situation.

That is really helping the battlers—it is not the rhetoric that we have been getting from the opposition. And it is very interesting, is it not, that the shadow minister for health and human resources, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), was not here to say anything in this discussion, that he was not here to discuss these issues as raised in the budget and, indeed, all of those matters that have become so important. The honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who spoke for the opposition, raised some questions about the National Health and Medical Research Council and I want to—
Opposition members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Order! The parliamentary secretary has the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to reply to the honourable member who raised these questions about the National Health and Medical Research Council. Let me say that that is doing an excellent job. It is taking up all the issues in a balanced way for a whole range of illnesses. As honourable members know, the government does not determine the spending areas. They are determined by the professionals themselves, by the availability of research, by the projects that are available. But I will refer those two matters back to the NHMRC, the two issues raised, and I will try to get some response for him. (Time expired)
