TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have got 30 seconds to speak, which I think is an utter disgrace. There are five minutes to talk about this. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) wants to talk about university places. I have not been able to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96. I have not been able to speak on this and this government should hang its head in shame for not allowing the opposition sufficient time to properly discuss this. It is an absolute disgrace and it should be put on the public record that I, as shadow minister, cannot speak on the appropriation or in this committee and debate it in detail.

—I am thankful that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) has deferred to me to allow me to say something about the fraud which has been perpetrated on the people of Queensland by the allocation of the so-called 4,200 extra university places; a fraud which is perpetrated on country people. I have expressed my fears about this situation for some time. There are 4,200 extra places, but, if these places are broken up over three years, and if the number of places is then broken up into the places which have to go to new universities in south-east Queensland, to Sippy Downs, to the extension of Griffith University on the Gold Coast and to the possible extension of the University of Queensland to Ipswich, it is obvious that 2,600 places have to go into that south-east corner just to keep pace. That leaves a total of 1,600 places for the rest of Queensland, of which 700 places will not be announced for another year or so.

PARA.TAB: I have found that, for the nine country universities—those from Toowoomba through Wide Bay, Burnett and Central Queensland to James Cook in North Queensland and its other campus at Cairns—the state of Queensland received 900 places spread over nine campuses over three years. Big deal! My area of Central Queensland has been given 420 extra places. The absolute minimum for Central Queensland is 500 places, and the academics at the University of Central Queensland are asking for an absolute minimum of 700 or 800 places. However, what do we find? We find that the 420 places are already bodgied up with 100 places which were pre-announced by the current Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) three years earlier. Out of this budget proper, we are allocated 320 places which are spread over five campuses. What a fraud! This is an area where, on a student to population ratio, we are allocated only 50 per cent of the Australian average of university places. Honourable members should note that.

After all this trumpeting, how many places does the Central Queensland area end up with? Our area ends up with 60 per cent. This area is so far behind the average for the rest of Australia that the situation is an utter disgrace. The allocation of the extra spaces is purported to be a great saviour, but my ALP opponent has not been very sage-like about the situation. My opponent jumped in boots-and-all and said what a marvellous thing it is. When I explained in the media what is to happen in our own area, and when the academics came out and agreed with me, my opponent ran one line in a newspaper in Bundaberg, and, in the Gladstone Observer, he stated that he is not pleased with the allocation. Once the situation with the places is explained to them, even ALP candidates are shown what a fraudulent situation it is.

This government is announcing things far in advance and then the government blocks them up, puts them one year forward or pulls them one year back. The government tops the places up when it suits the government to do so. By the time the government gets to the point of delivery, no-one quite remembers what they have got, and the universities and the regional campuses which are desperately in need of places do not know what is happening.

There is a classic case of a similar nature in the state budget, and I use it as an example of how the ALP got away with murder. The Bundaberg police station has been announced in four consecutive budgets. It was also announced in the state budget that the Bundaberg Base Hospital, which has had three front-page stories each announcing a $18.1 million new hospital development, is to be allocated $2.8 million. Of the $18.1 million which was originally announced, the hospital was allocated $2.8 million when the time came. That amount of money will not deliver one major building on the hospital campus. The universities are in the same situation.

This is a government of perpetual announcements, perpetual topping up and perpetual backing and filling. The situation with university places in Central Queensland is a disgrace and the allocation of 320 places over five campuses should be condemned. The allocation has left the people of Central Queensland with only 60 per cent of the average student to population ratio, and it is about time the government did something to correct the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the matters raised by the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville). In his contribution he did not focus all his attention on higher education but decided to talk about police stations and hospitals. They are not a part of this appropriation. That reflects the fact that the opposition does not want to talk about what has been a tremendous achievement in higher education over the last 12 years.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the number of students who complete secondary school and go on to higher education today compared with the number in 1983, taking Queensland as an example, there has been a huge turnaround in the number who complete secondary school and a massive increase in the number of new university places that have been provided. Indeed, the growth in university places across Australia over the last decade has been large enough to warrant the creation of another dozen or so educational institutions at higher education level. So the measures over the last 10 years have been substantial. The measures in this budget represent a further commitment by the government.

A number of additional places will be created in the 1996-98 triennium, and yet the member for Hinkler attempts to make some debating point about the fact that those arrangements are phased. That has always been the case. Announcements are made now for some years down the track. Obviously, growth regions such as Queensland, western Sydney—which the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), I and others represent—other parts of Queensland where there are high levels of growth, Western Australia, and the north coast of New South Wales, have all been keen to get more places. There is no argument about that.

The contents of this budget provide precisely those things. In the budget, it was made clear that there was going to be a strong additional commitment to providing places in Queensland. There was also a strong commitment to the growth regions of New South Wales and Western Australia. The government also ensured that the growth in those places, for which we are providing 5,850 new higher education places in the 1996-98 period, is being achieved without substantial impacts as far as HECS is concerned.

Certainly, none of the fees which students feared, and which they were campaigning about prior to the budget, have been introduced, and that was done without detriment to states such as Victoria and South Australia either. Queensland will receive 1,750 new places in 1996, a further 1,500 places in 1997 and 950 in 1998. No-one can say that the growth demand in Queensland—which no-one would argue with—is not being responded to by the government. It is being responded to. There are also further measures in the budget that recognise increased participation access requirements in Western Australia and New South Wales as well.

If we compared the approach of the government to that of the opposition—to the extent that we have a policy from the opposition in these areas—what would the opposition's approach be? I presume it would go back to what was offered in Fightback, with the emphasis on a user-pays approach, with vouchers and those sorts of arrangements to pay for higher education. How anyone could suggest that that adds to the access and equity issues of the growth centres in Queensland, I am not too sure.

What I do know is that the government has made a strong commitment to add to the places in the growth centres. That strong commitment is recognised by the fact that the budget announcements ensure 5,850 new higher education places in the 1996-98 triennium. We also made it clear that a substantial additional injection would be made into the TAFE system, as well as providing the reinforcing measures that are contained in the budget relating to improving accessibility in terms of the transition between school and TAFE, the ANTA arrangements, and so on.

In terms of the allocations in this area of higher education, the growth centres do very well out of this budget. The government is maintaining its commitment to ensure proper access to the places that are needed in Queensland and in all the other growth areas of Australia. Those arrangements must be continued. Our commitment to the higher education sector stands in stark contrast to the elitist approach under the previous Liberal-National Party government.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the Department of Social Security and I may have some time to deal with some aspects of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. For even the truest believers in the government the real crunch must have come with the release of the Gregory study which showed that under Labor the rich have got rich and the poor have got poorer. There could be no more damning indictment of the government than after 12 years of programs, programs, programs—a program for every problem, most of which the government created in the first place—this is the outcome. It is unarguable. The facts are there: the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer. No more evidence is needed of the abject failure of the economic and social policies of this government.

PARA.TAB: The government has put in place the preconditions for a permanent underclass, despite all of the programs. A moment ago I was listening to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) raving on about the social wage. We debated that in the parliament today. These programs all comprise the social wage. In this country we have ended up with what is effectively a welfare state which has failed to delivery anything but dependency. When those opposite rave on about the social wage that is what they are talking about. There are many people in this country now receiving the social wage. I cannot see that that is something to crow about; it is something of which the government ought to be ashamed.

Many people in this country are now absolutely dependent on what those opposite call the social wage. I wonder whether it is intentional. I assume the government has gone about creating this situation where more and more people are locked into the government system, relying each week, fortnight, month or whatever on the government's handouts just to survive. Is that the sort of Australia that the we really want to create? It is the sort of Australia that the government has ended up creating.

Let me ask the one big question that is on the lips of most people about the budget: where are my tax cuts? We will not let those opposite forget that. That was a promise. It was locked in before the last election which the government won through deceit. Since that election the government has backtracked on that promise.

The fact that the government has not delivered those tax cuts affects many people in our community—particularly people in my electorate who are part-pensioners and self-funded retirees. I ask the question: what is the government doing for those people? Self-funded retirees and part-pensioners are going to lose because they are not receiving their tax cuts. There is no compensation in the budget for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish; it is a fact. The point is that they would have received tax cuts. They were looking forward to receiving tax cuts. We will be told that that decision is somehow a win-win situation. The budget shows savings of the order of $200 million in respect of that particular item. Many people are going to lose money as a result of that. I am alluding to the government's decision about out deeming.

PARA.TAB: On numerous occasions in this parliament I have raised the question of income testing of unrealised capital gains. We are delighted to see that go. But the government has replaced it with a deeming provision. When it settles down and the fine print is read, people will realise that they are going to lose some of their pensions. The government is saving money. Where are the savings coming from if they are not going to come from people who are now receiving part-pensions and who are going to lose those part-pensions?

There may be some gains, there may be some winners on that, but there will be losers. There will be losers simply because there are some share portfolios that are not showing returns of five or seven per cent. What does the government say to those people? Will those opposite say what the former parliamentary secretary said—sell off?.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sell off.

—Sell your shares. With this system the government is saying that pensioners cannot have shares. Pensioners will not be able to have share portfolios any more. They will not be able to risk losing their part-pensions because they are not achieving five or seven per cent yields. If we look at all the bluechip investments in Australia we will find very few of them are yielding anywhere in the order of five or seven per cent, depending upon where the actual cut-off point is.

PARA.TAB: So pensioners, part-pensioners in particular, and self-funded retirees are certainly major losers under this budget. We cannot cover too much in the time that is remaining. I would like to talk about families—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of points that have been raised in this debate and in the limited time I have I would certainly like to answer them. I will answer them in total if I can. A point I must make at the very beginning of my reply is that what has affected the opposition is not only the quality of this budget that has just been brought down but also the absolutely overwhelming response we have had from pensioners and pensioner groups, from carers, from single parents, from mothers across Australia. The kudos that has come and the response that we have got from the community in general have been tremendous.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) mentioned a report that was done by Gregory and Hunter. That particular firm took census figures for 1976, 1981, 1986 and 1991, and went on to suggest the very substantial widening of income differences. But he did not go on with the evidence showing, for example, that the average household is being affected by female participation in the labour force, how it is rising in that particular area, how the income of the poorest group has risen. That has certainly not been recorded in his figures, nor have Gregory and Hunter chosen to take that up in some of their statistics. What the honourable member must do in future is read all of the facts, and then he will get a true interpretation of what we are talking about in social security.

One of the things that are affecting the opposition is this wonderful report that was certainly not put out by us but by an independent journalist, Deborah Hope, in the Weekend Australian of 3 June. Perhaps I should give the honourable member a copy of it and ask him to read it. It discusses how the word `underclass' is being thrown around by assorted critics of Australia's social state. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's effective in debate—it has a credible, alarming and unacceptable ring about it. There is only one problem—it describes a group that doesn't really exist.

She then went on with a great degree of independent assessment of what is recognised now as one of the greatest social security systems in the world—an independent journalist, an independent assessment of it. Again, that has not come up in the debate.

PARA.TAB: As for deeming, I would expect that the opposition would come around and admit that what has been put into place now with deeming for our pensioner groups is one of the fairest ways of assessing income and taking into account retirees, both pensioners and part-pensioners, who have their income invested. It also has to be acknowledged that what we have put into place is not something that occurred last week, or will occur next week; it comes into effect in July 1996. We have given those people an opportunity to look at the whole structure of their finances and where they can go. It is not something that is going to be brought in retrospectively.

It was very pleasing to note that both financial institutions and pensioner groups who have been affected at times in the past by deeming have congratulated our minister and the government at large, saying, `We thank you for listening. We thank you for bringing down a very fair response as far as the deeming legislation is concerned.' And that is what it is all about. We need to continually assess the changes in the environment at large that we have to deal with in social security, but most particularly, as I say time and time again in the House, we need to make sure that legislation is not set in concrete, that we are able to amend legislation to meet the concerns of the people affected and are able to make sure that there is a fair distribution of the tax dollar to those people who are in need. That is the difference between those opposite and us. We look at the people in need and we assess the criteria in social welfare and social security which should make for adequate payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the tax cuts?

—As for the tax cuts, I do not hear the honourable member or any other opposition members getting up and acknowledging the first lot of tax cuts that were put into place on wages up to $50,000 and also in the lower tax scales. We do not hear explanations coming forward on that or what has happened since then and how people have been able to benefit from it. But one of the things we have got to realistically take on board is the fact that a lot of those people will in the terms of their natural lives probably receive, in social security payments or in other payments afforded to them under the social security structure, a lot more than they would ever have sacrificed in the tax cut that they did not receive in the last year or two of their working lives.

PARA.TAB: Those people who go on part pension or those people who have independent incomes that are supplemented by another payment under Social Security will certainly benefit from the structures that we have put into place. Whether it is in the deeming structure, whether it is what we have been able to do in bringing them onto health care cards, all of their benefits have to be acknowledged. In social security, you do not take one single issue and say, `This is where they are being deprived.' You take it in total and you look at the whole structure of what we are on about in the implementation of social security in general. What we are talking about here is a very fair budget. It is a budget that particularly in the Social Security area has been just and is certainly distributing to a lot of people. It is, as they say, a great budget as far as the people at large are concerned. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditures agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $442,858,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of these appropriations, I want to raise the failure of the government, with all of the money that is being appropriated, to be able to respond to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, as it then was, on conditional migrant entry. That report was in December 1992. It contained a large number of recommendations. The reason I raise this matter now is that I become quite despondent when I have large numbers of people approaching me, both in my electorate and also more broadly as a member of the present migration committee of the parliament, asking some fairly basic questions about how they can access Australia when a health problem presents.

PARA.TAB: In that committee report, there were a number of positive recommendations that provided for an up-front payment that might allow people who had been determined as having a potential cost to Australia to be able to access Australia. It also provided some greater element of discretion to the minister in looking at particularly difficult cases. One of the points I would like to make is that it becomes very apparent that, time and time again, there are people for whom there is a substantial economic benefit to Australia if they are able to migrate here but who, because of a health problem of a particular family member, find it difficult to access Australia. This was the problem that was identified by the parliamentary committee 3 1/2 years ago, which it sought to have redressed, and to which the government has failed to respond.

There are other aspects of this question that also relate to other issues of a health nature. One of them relates to the question of the extent to which state authorities are notified of the presence within a state of people who are diagnosed as suffering tuberculosis or hepatitis B, when they come into Australia, to enable the appropriate public health strategies to be implemented. One would have thought that that was a pressing matter of very considerably urgency. In public hearings, before a committee of parliament, the issue was raised of tuberculosis and the way in which people have presented with some indication that this disease might still be with them or could potentially recur in Australia.

Yet we still have very significant problems in terms of notification to state authorities and, similarly, with the recommendations dealing with hepatitis B. I note also that there was considerable concern about the extent to which people who were non-permanent residents—that is, temporary residents—might be able to access Australia and, in particular, access Medicare and obtain services in Australia as a result of being temporarily here. Some recommendations were made on those issues and the government has not seen fit to respond to them either.

It is a deplorable situation. I would hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) might be in a position to give us some program as to how the government intends to deal with the matter. It may well be that it will be a new government that needs to address these issues. We should consider that it has taken some 3 1/2 years, when the standard practice for replying to reports of parliamentary committees is that they should be responded to within three months. It has not occurred in this instance, and it is an outrageous situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that, at the very beginning of the speech of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), when he got up to speak on migration, I actually went and looked at the details of the appropriation. This was because the government was listening and was taking on board the recommendations that were made by that committee. Those recommendations have gone through two different ministers. What has come forward, as the member for Berowra well knows, we have taken on board, time and time again.

As the honourable member for Berowra never had a thing to criticise on those estimates, we can only assume on this side of the House that when there is no criticism forthcoming he is actually congratulating the government.

The member for Berowra stands here, in a 1995-96 estimates debate, and talks about a 1992 report. He asks what is the government going to do in respect of the health requirements of those particular people who may not be permanent residents in this country.

This is not ridiculous; this has gone to the extreme. This is absolutely ridiculous. Why cannot we debate the credible funding of the immigration portfolio through this committee so that it can go and be judged on that? Why do we not have a debate on that? Why do we not have an input on that? The only reason we do not have a debate on it and we do not have input from the opposition on it is that the opposition is saying, `Congratulations, government, well done. Congratulations, government, you have done the estimates well. Congratulations, government, you are caring for immigration.' And, most particularly, it is saying, `Congratulations, government, you know what you are on about; you know what you are doing.' It is this government that has been able to put immigration in fair and structured clauses. This government has been able to do that.

The honourable member who led for the opposition is speaking for the opposition and is representing his people in an estimates debate, and he has come up with—I repeat for the Hansard—a 1992 report. I cannot off the top of my head tell honourable members who are listening to this debate and those who may be tuned in in their offices how many reports have been brought down since then. How many pieces of legislation were brought in to acknowledge and to bring into accord changes that needed to be made to the act? What do we have? The member for Berowra gets up and laments the fact that we are bringing down legislation for change. I say to the member for Berowra that we are here to discuss estimates. Again I say to him, `Thank you for the compliment you have paid to this government and to our minister for immigration. Thank you for the support that you have given to the structure and the financial structure of the debate. We will appreciate that and take that on board.' (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me I would like to get back to some of the comments that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made in relation to transport in question time today. Notwithstanding the censure motion was on one particular issue, I would like to take issue with some of the misleading comments that the Prime Minister made then in relation to transport. He was talking about the final link in the standard gauge between Melbourne and Adelaide. While we are all pleased to see that occur, he then went on to talk about the fact that they can now bring double-stacked wagons through, including through to Melbourne. He mentioned Melbourne. I heard that distinctly.
—He did not.

—I thought, `Wow,' and there we are. They cannot bring double stacked into Melbourne because, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) knows, they cannot get them through the Adelaide Hills. The Prime Minister went on again to talk about the lack of coalition contribution to the standard gauge development. Of course, he very conveniently overlooked the fact that it was the coalition that converted the Alice Springs to Adelaide line, the coalition that converted the Broken Hill to Port Pirie line. It was a coalition some years ago that actually converted the Sydney to Melbourne line to standard gauge. If we look at some of the developments during the previous coalition governments until the last four or five years, it was the coalition government that had a much better record when it came to capital expenditure on railways than the Hawke government. The Hawke government virtually starved Australian National of capital and it had to go heavily into debt to try to do some of its equipment replacement. I think that is something that was very much overlooked by the Prime Minister. It shows that when it comes to rail he likes to fudge the facts just as he likes to do on a number of other issues.

PARA.TAB: We looked at another area of transport that he was trying to admonish the opposition about—fuel tax. Yet it is the Labor government that has increased fuel tax almost exponentially. It was the Labor government that increased it after the 1992 election. It is the Labor government that is going to increase fuel tax again in July this year. So that is very much part of this budget debate. At the same time, it is the Labor government that has been progressively reducing the Commonwealth contribution to road funding. So if we look at the facts: from 1983-84 when over 60 per cent of fuel tax went into Commonwealth road funding, we find that today it is less than 10 per cent. At the same time, the Commonwealth's contribution to road funding in real terms has almost halved. In fact, it is under $800 million for the coming financial year.

Then we can look at some of the other areas where this Labor government has failed in providing a world class transport system. That ought to be one of the fundamental things. If we are going to get this country really going, we ought to be looking at what we can do. We look in the area of regulation of road transport. Despite report after report, despite all the promises, we still have not got uniform road regulations right across this country. This government and the Commonwealth itself, as we know, have failed to bring in the latest bit of legislation that is supposed to be doing something about this.

We can look at a number of other areas, remembering that time is limited. I talked about fuel tax and road expenditure. We can look at the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and the report that was brought down by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He was a former transport minister in the Labor government. As he pointed out, nearly one in five dollars being spent on infrastructure in road building is probably being wasted; as he pointed out also, we could spend almost $1 billion more on road construction and not have to find another dollar. He was talking about the total expenditure nationally of $5 billion. The point that he was making, and I am glad to see the parliamentary secretary nodding his head, was that this should be done.

Having been in government for 12 years, however, what has the government done about it? The government has had 12 years. This report came out only just over a year ago and shows that the government has really been a failure. There is a very limited amount of time here and I just wanted to highlight these points to show that in some areas in transport the government's record is a very sad one. It has failed to provide a world-class transport system. What we have seen in so many areas is a government of perpetual announcement, where it announces and reannounces how it is going to do things but somehow they just never quite seem to get done. Unfortunately, all Australians, particularly those living in regional and rural Australia, are suffering because the government has failed to grasp the nettle on this whole transport issue and has failed to provide a world-class transport system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel some need to enlarge on a couple of points that have been made by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1995-96. I cannot believe that he can actually stand there and say those things with a serious face, knowing that they are just not right. Let us just quickly run through them.

PARA.TAB: Yes, we had the standard gauge event yesterday. What a wonderful achievement for Australian Rail—a wonderful achievement, a great symbol for the nation, as the honourable member concedes. The opposition had 30 years to do it. The opposition had 23 years to do it between 1949 and 1972 and another seven years between 1975 and 1982—that is 30 years to do it. The opposition had five state Liberal governments to do it with, and still could not manage it. Gough Whitlam actually offered to buy the railways from the Liberal state governments and he could not even pay for them; so in the end we have got them to hand the railways over. We have been able to do it; we have injected this $400 million; and now, as the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) announced on Saturday night in his speech in Melbourne, there is a further proposal for Track Australia, which will become the authority to run the track around the nation, and, providing the government can get the structure in place for the next stage of reform, a further investment of another $500 million in rail in Australia, which is unprecedented in rail in Australia.

On the fuel tax problem, I think the opposition actually believes what it goes around saying—firstly, that the federal government allocates only $800 million for road funds, and that only 3c or 4c of the fuel tax goes into roads. What the opposition conveniently forgets to mention every time we discuss this is that the federal government hands to states and to local government an amount in excess of $2 billion of untied funds which is spent on roads. Not only do we do this, but state governments ask us to tell them that it is for the roads, because their various treasurers otherwise want to hop into it for other reasons. Who asked for this untied road funding formula? The state governments asked for it, and most of them were Liberal state governments asking for it.

We have this very interesting little proposal where the opposition claims that the federal government only invests $800 million in roads. Yet, as the committee chaired by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) showed, $5 billion a year is spent in Australia on roads. Where does it come from? State taxes. And when we break down those state taxes and the revenue, it is the untied grants that come from the federal government, in the majority.

Members of the opposition also never mention the $6 billion worth of costs associated with road safety—and I am talking about cleaning up the mess from all the road accidents. The Bureau of Transport Economics costs that at $6 billion a year. What pays for that? Who pays for the ambulances, the hospitals and all of that? It comes out of untied funds that the federal government hands over.

They never ever think about the $2 billion worth of environmental costs associated with pollution and all the other issues that we are funding in one way or another. Who do they think pays for it? The petrol tax argument is a dud. They do not do themselves any grace. Even the Road Transport Forum has given it away. Even the automobile associations have given it away. Show me when they last ran the petrol tax argument. They have given it away; they know it is a junk argument. The honourable member for Wannon is the last person in Australia running this argument.

I could not believe he raised the uniform charges and regulations issue, because what did we do? We set up the National Road Transport Commission, with the cooperation of the state governments, and we set about the process of putting in place uniform legislation. The federal government, with the cooperation of the opposition, has passed every bit of legislation through the parliament the minute it has hit the deck. Who is holding it up? Poor old Eric Charlton, Western Australian Liberal Minister for Transport. He is the one who will not sign up. Bruce Baird was holding us up. Michael Knight and Brian Langton, the new ministers in the new government in New South Wales, said, `Yes, we are there. We will sign up straightaway, as soon as Western Australia does.' Who is holding us all up? A Western Australian state Liberal. How could the honourable member fall for that? How could he come in here and set his own party's state transport minister up like that? These are a few quick points and I think the government has a solid process in place. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $162,885,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is opportune that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) is here, although he is on his way out. I just came in on the tail end of his apology for the absolute damage that the Maritime Union has wreaked in Western Australia, when one considers that, as a result of what they have done, Stateships is now being closed. I think that as the parliamentary secretary, presumably somebody who is attuned to a rational solution to the problems on the waterfront, he would have been immensely shocked by that particular decision. I would have thought he would have been spending his time going and talking to the representatives of the MUA and endeavouring to arrive at some rational solution to the impasse at the Fremantle waterfront.

PARA.TAB: The reason I have come to make a contribution to this particular debate is that, a week or so ago, I happened to be at a function in my electorate—in fact, it was a play at one of the local high schools—and the fellow who was sitting next to me happened to be the operator of a business that used imported hard timber as part of his furniture manufacturing operations. His is a very small operation, essentially operating and providing supplies and equipment for craftsmen—people who are furniture makers or woodworkers at home. This chap, in a small way, had a $25,000 consignment of timber that was in a container ship that was heading towards the Fremantle wharves at that time. Because of the dispute, it headed off out into the ocean again. As he said to me, he did not know where it was at the particular stage I was talking to him. But here in a physical sense is a direct result of this type of industrial disputation. This is someone who employed, I think, two people—not a great deal—whose very business, his livelihood, was being threatened by the actions on the waterfront of the militant MUA.

The Western Australian government has been pilloried to a certain extent by those who have seen it as their role to do so. For what? For trying to introduce some basic reforms to bring down the costs of the operation of the waterfront at Fremantle. These are costs that are crippling businesses in Western Australia, that make Fremantle a less attractive port of call or place where cargo is transhipped, a place where there are inordinate delays, and an obvious place for the sorts of reforms that have been cried out for for a long time indeed. Many of the people who are going to be affected in the short to medium term by this disputation are ordinary small businesses being operated by average Australians who obviously employ a large number of other Australians because, as we do know, small business is one of the principal employer groups within Australia.

At the end of the day, we have a situation where, in order to effect a relatively simple reform—that is, to try to bring down the costs of stevedoring at Fremantle—we are going to see a situation where Stateships is closed down. I might add that, in the first instance, the state government was urged to close Stateships some time ago. It was kept operating, but it was running at a loss—a huge loss. That loss is passed on to every single consumer, not only in Western Australia but elsewhere because, in the end, it does not matter how you factor the cost of increased costs or losses. They inevitably go to the consumer, the ordinary Australian—in our case, the ordinary Western Australian—who has to pay more for the items that are transhipped via the Fremantle wharf or that travel on Stateships.

In the concluding moments of my speech, all I can do is urge the federal Labor government to use its good office to try to get the MUA to cooperate with what are quite simple, rational and commonsense reforms. Those reforms will ensure that Western Australians, and other Australian consumers, are able to enjoy the services of stevedoring and, of course, of Stateships transport at a lower cost—a lower net loss—to them.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $547,573,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have available I only wish to raise one subject, and that is the question of where, in this appropriation, is the encouragement for hardwood plantations and the like? I noticed the other day that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) was in the south-east of South Australia and he was quite flattering—as he should be—in describing that area as a model for softwood plantations. After 70 or 80 years and 230,000 acres of plantations, that seems to me a slight underdescription. Nevertheless, he said that there was a tremendous amount that could be achieved in the south-east of South Australia with plantation forestry and value-adding. Well, I agree; so much so that a couple of weeks before he was there we had a meeting in Mount Gambier of 100 growers looking at how we could increase hardwood plantations in the south-east of South Australia with a view to exporting more woodchips.

PARA.TAB: The minister said that he believed that the tree farms or softwood plantations should be encouraged. Where are they being encouraged in this appropriation? I cannot find it. He said that this is bringing great benefits to the rest of Australia in terms of export markets. That is so obvious that it did not need saying. He said that that is something to be encouraged and which the Commonwealth strongly supports. How is that encouraged in this appropriation?

The minister also said that he anticipated a relative reduction in the harvesting of old growth hardwood forests as plantations increased. The problem with that is that, if we are talking about chips, then I can understand what he is saying. However, if we are talking about logs for construction purposes and so forth, which take from 40 to 80 and even up to 120 years to grow, how is the government going to encourage that production? I have seen nothing in this appropriation to show that the government is encouraging, as the minister says, the phase-out of logging and forestry operations in high conservation value areas.

The opposition has no problem with all those evaluations being made. The opposition has no problem with regional agreements based on that high conservation assessment. What the opposition does have a problem with is finding where the government is encouraging plantations for long-term logging purposes—that is, as a substitute to native forests—anywhere in this appropriation.

What one would be looking for—if not in the appropriation itself, then in policy—would be some form of tax arrangement which gave encouragement to those people who might be considering an investment of 20 years, 30 years, 45 years, 80 years or whatever to produce a certain type of timber. However, I cannot find that. It seems that nobody in the government has thought about the fact that for the potential investor—who after all is investing not for himself or for his kids, but for his grandchildren and who already has private, cleared land in the right rainfall area—there is no encouragement to substitute the logs of the future for the native forests of today.

I travelled to that area the other day with the chairman of one of those companies. He looked out the window of the plane and said, `Isn't it nice to know that that forest of ours is growing at two tonnes a minute.' He was referring to the 45,000-acre forest owned by his company. The plantation industry, properly planned and properly encouraged, presents an enormous investment opportunity for this country.

There is a lot of criticism of Western Australians in this place, but the Western Australians, through the Department of Conservation and Land Management, have initiated long-term international contracts with the Japanese and the Koreans. TALK.START.PARA: —This being the consideration in detail of the appropriations for the Attorney-General's Department, and given that there is five minutes for either side, one cannot deal with much detail in that time. I wish to concentrate my remarks on one aspect of the appropriation for the Attorney-General's Department: namely some of the programs provided through the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services. I do that in the context that there is something in our human nature that makes us want to connect with, to nurture, and to care for one another.

PARA.TAB: It seems to be a basic human instinct to care for and be cared for by others, to reach out to those about us and to create relationships in which we find meaning and identity in an often alienating and confusing world. People find something joyful about their relationships in human terms and in the connections that they are able to make with others. Given this powerful human instinct, it saddens me that so much of the time that we spend in this parliament, and in making our laws, is spent on dealing with disconnection and with the breaking down of relationships rather than on something to help people to nurture and build their relationships.

It is in this context that I wish to say a few words and ask a couple of questions about the estimates for the family services programs. One reads in the Justice Statement that various amounts of money are being promised over a four-year period. There is a reference in there to $12.3 million to enable more marriage and relationship preparation courses and another reference to $4 million for the same thing. There is also reference to $2.7 million for programs for non-English speakers and $2.8 million for family skills. When we look at the exact figures there seems to be double counting but, and this is one of the problems, we cannot find out the exact appropriations for these various programs for 1995-96.

In evidence to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues a week ago, the Acting First Assistant Secretary to the department, Dr Margaret Browne, said that the additional appropriation for marriage education in 1995-96 would be $66,000; adolescent mediation would be $36,000; family skills would be $360,000; and, counselling, nothing. However, in evidence before the Senate estimates committee, the same Dr Browne said that, in relation to marriage education, the additional expenditure would be $707,000, and she repeated that figure to the committee four times. In relation to adolescent mediation, the figure she gave was not $36,000 but the additional figure of $393,000. For family skills, she said that the additional figure is not the one quoted earlier of $360,000 but the additional figure of $393,000.

Just to add some more confusion to the picture, I got a letter from Dr Browne today in relation to each of those programs. She says in there that the additional funding for marriage education is $665,000, that for family skills it is $360,000 and that for the adolescent mediation program it is $360,000. I now have three different sets of figures. The only consistency in them is that the figure for the increase in marriage counselling on all three occasions was given as nothing. I have written to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) asking him to clarify what seems, on the face of the evidence given, and in that letter to me, a confusing situation as to what the funding is for these programs. I do not think that that should be too much to ask.

This is the third or fourth year that there has not been any real increase in funding for marriage counselling and that is clear on all of the answers. In evidence to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, we heard from the Director of Counselling Services at Relationships Australia in Adelaide that there are delays in that agency of three to four weeks—other agencies talk of delays of six to eight weeks—yet we have no increase whatsoever in funding for marriage counselling. Finally, and I have made this point before, let us look at the balance between the building up of relationships, nurturing and supporting them and the consequences of marriage breakdowns. We give a few million dollars to the building of relationships, and this budget gives additional funding, which I support, and yet we spend about $3,000 million a year on the consequences of marriage breakdowns. TALK.START.PARA: asked all Portfolio Ministers, upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's Department calculated what its tax obligations would be if the national competition policy proposed by the Hilmer Committee of Inquiry was fully implemented; if so, what is the best estimate of the Department's annual local government rates liability throughout Australia.
(2) What other (a) financial and (b) non-financial effects would the full implementation of the proposed national competition policy have on the Department's activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided on behalf of all Portfolio Ministers to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The national competition policy proposed by the Hilmer Committee largely establishes reform processes rather than specific reforms in individual sectors.

With respect to taxation, the national competition policy reforms establish a set of principles designed to achieve competitive neutrality between government and private businesses. These principles do not require the Commonwealth to impose taxes on Departmental businesses because they cannot be obliged to pay taxes.

On the issue of Departmental liability for local government rates, section 114 of the Constitution precludes States from imposing any tax on property belonging to the Commonwealth, without the consent of the Commonwealth Parliament. However, Departments presently operate under Finance Directions which allow the gratuitous payment to local governments of an amount equivalent to general rates in circumstances where such costs will be demonstrably passed on to third parties. These circumstances might arise where, for example, a Commonwealth Department uses property for a commercial undertaking and includes the cost of rates in its pricing structure. It is not anticipated that implementation of the Hilmer Report will change this policy.

(2)(a) and (b) Discussions with State and Territory Governments on implementation of the Hilmer Report have been in train since the Hilmer Report's release in August 1993. Draft legislation and inter-governmental agreements were released for public comment. Revised legislation was introduced to the Senate on 29 March 1995, and revised inter-governmental agreements were executed at the Council of Australian Governments meeting on 11 April 1995.

The Hilmer Report has six main elements, which will have varying effects on the activities of Departments. Financial effects may include a possible slight lowering of the prices of goods and services purchased by Departments, arising from increased competition within the economy. Non-financial effects will include the work associated with the involvement of Departments in the implementation of reforms flowing from the proposed national competition policy.

The first element of the Hilmer Report is legislation affecting the operation of the competition provisions contained in Part IV of the Trade Practices Act. The amendments involve extension of Part IV of that Act to currently exempt businesses. There are also some technical amendments to the form of the prohibitions. Commonwealth Departments are already bound by the Trade Practices Act, and it is not expected that the amendments to that Act will have a significant effect upon Departments' activities. There is likely to be some impact on State Government departments and authorities which are not currently bound by that Act.

The second element of the Hilmer Report is a process for reform of regulation that unjustifiably restricts competition. Under the inter-governmental Competition Principles Agreement the Commonwealth is required to develop a process for the review of legislation that restricts competition, to ensure that the benefits of the restriction to the community as a whole outweigh the costs and that the objectives of the legislation can only be achieved by restricting competition. Various Departments will be involved in reviews of legislation, and as a result of the review processes some legislation administered by Departments is likely to be amended.

The third element of the Hilmer Report relates to the structural reform of public monopolies. The Competition Principles Agreement requires the Commonwealth to ensure that before introducing competition to a sector traditionally supplied by a public monopoly, it will remove from the public monopoly any responsibilities for industry regulation. The Commonwealth is also required, before introducing competition to a market traditionally supplied by a public monopoly, or before privatising a public monopoly, to undertake a review to ensure that various policy matters are duly taken into consideration. These requirements do not commit the Commonwealth to the introduction of competition in particular sectors or to the privatisation of particular commercial operations. Nevertheless, where Commonwealth Departments do propose to introduce competition to a sector traditionally supplied by a public monopoly, or to privatise a public monopoly, they will need to ensure compliance with the Agreement.

The fourth element of the Hilmer Report is the establishment of a legal regime permitting, in certain circumstances, third parties to have access to certain facilities, such as electricity transmission grids or gas pipelines, which are essential for competition in related markets. The access regime will be established in a new Part of the Trade Practices Act. It is not at this stage expected that it will be applied to facilities currently owned or operated by Commonwealth Departments.

The fifth element of the Hilmer Report relates to prices surveillance. The legislation which was introduced into Parliament contains a number of amendments to the Prices Surveillance Act, including the introduction of ongoing formal monitoring of prices charged by businesses. The PSA is to be merged with the Trade Practices Commission to form a new competition authority. Commonwealth Departments are already potentially subject to scrutiny under the Prices Surveillance Act, although occasions on which Departments have actually been subjected to such scrutiny have been rare. It is not expected that the amendments to that Act will have any significant impact upon the activities of Commonwealth Departments. There is likely to be some impact on State Government Departments and authorities which are not currently subject to that Act.

The final element of the Hilmer Report relates to the competitive neutrality of Government businesses. The Competition Principles Agreement requires the Commonwealth to develop a policy statement on competitive neutrality, with the objective being that Government businesses should not enjoy any net competitive advantage simply as a result of their public sector ownership. The effects of implementation of this element of the Hilmer package will not be determined until the Commonwealth develops its policy statement on competitive neutrality.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A breakdown of civil marriage celebrant authorisations for the whole of Australia are:
(2) Yes
(2)(a) The selection criteria used are as follows
CIVIL MARRIAGE CELEBRANT PROGRAM: SELECTION CRITERIA

Authorisation as a civil marriage celebrant under section 39(2) of the Marriage Act 1961 is both a serious and important appointment within the Australian community. Those appointed should be persons who will make a positive contribution to the establishment and maintenance of marriage and the family in the Australian community and be a suitable person to represent the Commonwealth in this role.
1. Public Speaking

The applicant will be required to speak in a public setting to both small and large groups of people in the performance of the role of solemnising a marriage. Applicants need to have proven experience and ability in the art of public speaking. Applicants will be required to have the ability to address groups in a confident manner and style as well as in an appropriate manner befitting the solemnity required in the formal setting of a wedding ceremony.
2. Community/Civic Involvement:
The civil marriage celebrant is authorised to provide a service to the community. Applicants should be prominent in community affairs and be adding value to the society in which they live.
3. Understanding of Legislative Provisions and the Ability to Convey the Salient Requirements of a Piece of Legislation to a Third Party:

Civil marriage celebrants must have or be able to rapidly acquire an understanding of the appropriate parts of the Marriage Act 1961 sufficient to convey to couples their rights and duties under the law in respect of the married state. Applicants will be required to demonstrate either experience or ability in acquiring an understanding of the provisions of a piece of legislation and the ability to convey this understanding to a third party. Applicants will be required to demonstrate the ability to fulfil the administrative requirements of the celebrant role as varied from time to time.
4. General Suitability

By virtue of the appointment, civil marriage celebrants are representatives of the community and the authority of the Commonwealth. They are called upon to establish the couple as a legal entity in the eyes of the state and to confer the community's approval of the couple's union. As such, this role is central to community life and the maintenance of marriage and the family as an institution supporting society. Applicants, in keeping this dual role must:
demonstrate an appropriate sense of integrity in performing the role;
not have a criminal record;
not have a conflict of interest or potential for such a conflict of interest in connection with either their business interests, hobbies or other interests.
NOTE: Applicants will be required to provide the name and address of two referees to attest to their character and general suitability.
(b) Selection criteria are applied in the authorisation of all civil marriage celebrants.
(3) Yes.
(a) I am advised that all the 562 persons appointed in 1995 up to March 1995 applied before 1 July 1994.

(b) The date of receipt of applications is not recorded on the Departmental database. I am advised that Legal Aid and Family Services do not have the resources to undertake the manual extraction of information required to provide a precise answer to the honourable member's question. However, during this appointment process, applications received between 1984 and the imposition of the moratorium on applications on 30 November 1993 were considered.

(4) Following authorisation, civil celebrants are provided with Information for New Celebrants, Schedule of fees, Advertising Guidelines and a List of contact numbers of the various Registries of Births, Deaths & Marriages throughout Australia. A Handbook is also provided which contains the Marriage Act and Regulations as well as an Explanatory Memorandum. The Explanatory Memorandum is provided by Legal Aid and Family Services to assist celebrants in their role. Celebrants are also invited to contact the department or the State Registries of Births, Deaths and Marriages at any time.

(5)(a) Since 1 January 1992, 42 instruments authorising civil marriage celebrants have been revoked. In addition, the appointment of all Australian marriage officers at Australian overseas posts were revoked, with effect from 1 January 1995, by the Attorney-General, at the request of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Under the Marriage Regulations, the Attorney-General may appoint as a marriage officer a person appointed to hold or act in the office of Ambassador, High Commissioner, Counsellor or Secretary at an Embassy, High Commissioner's Office, Legation or other post, or Consul.
(b) Authorisations allow celebrants to solemnise a marriage at any place in Australia. No authorisations have been amended.
(i) In 1992 there were 19 revocations: 9 in 1993: 13 in 1994: and one in 1995.
(ii) & (iii) Revocations have been made at the request of the celebrants when tendering their resignations.

(6)(a) Legal Aid and Family Services investigate all complaints received in writing in respect of compliance with advertising standards. In most cases no further action has been taken. Where appropriate, Legal Aid and Family Services has reprimanded the celebrant. I am advised that, in the judgement of the Department, no breaches have been serious enough to justify revocation.
(b) Legal Aid and Family Services investigate all complaints received in writing in respect of compliance with charging prescribed fees.

(c) All marriages are registered with the Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages in the State or Territory in which they were performed. Where a question arises as to the validity of a marriage, the Registry refers the matter to the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department for further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 29 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did she collaborate with Cleo magazine to publish the safe sex guide which appeared in the December 1994 issue; if so, why.
(2) Was the guide a Government initiative; if so, (a) what statistics were used in selecting Cleo to publish it and (b) were tenders called from other magazine publishers.
(3) Did she or her Department (a) prepare and (b) endorse material in the guide; if so, was the objective of the guide to promote safe anal intercourse and not to discourage anal intercourse.

(4) Did she or her Department take account of the age groupings of Cleo's readership; if so (a) what is the breakdown, (b) from whom were the figures derived and (c) what proportion of the readership comprises teenagers.
(5) Did she or her Department intend that teenagers be exposed to the contents of the guide.
(6) Did the Commonwealth fund the publication of the guide; if so, what was the benefit to the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) My Department commissioned Cleo to produce a Safe Sex Guide to be banded to the December 1994 issue of Cleo magazine.

The Department funded the Guide following recent research indicating that the majority of young people aged eighteen years and over are sexually active. Research evidence further indicates that young people are engaging in a wide variety of sexual behaviours, including anal intercourse. It is essential therefore that these young people be presented with information that is factual and accessible.

Research undertaken by the Family Planning Association indicates that for 63% of young women, the main sources of information on health matters are magazines and books. This is supported by recent research (Survey on the National Policy on the Health of Young Australians, 1995) which indicates that for 59.8% of young people, the most common sources of information about health are magazines and books.
The guide is consistent with the promotion of safe sexual practices which has been a theme of all Australian Governments in recent years.
(2) The Safe Sex Guide was an initiative of the Department of Human Services and Health.

The Department considered a number of popular women's magazines, including Cleo, New Woman, and Cosmo. The Department selected Cleo for several reasons. Firstly, the circulation of Cleo is higher than that of other Women's magazines; and secondly because Cleo readers are predominantly women aged 18 to 35 years, which reflects the target audience of the project. These figures were obtained through Cleo magazine, which obtains its figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations and Morgan.

(3) Under the arrangements with Australian Consolidated Press editorial control remained with Cleo. Cleo journalists wrote the articles in the style which they knew would be attractive to the target audience of young people between 18 and 35 years of age.
An advisory committee consisting of appropriate experts was established by the Department to oversight the process.

I endorse the Guide's approach to safe sex. Supporting the need to communicate with young adults in a way that is meaningful to them does not necessarily mean a personal endorsement of either the sexual behaviours discussed, or the style in which the articles are written. My view is that the sexual preferences and practices of consenting adults are issues for each individual to consider. My concern is that people have appropriate information easily available to them so that, whatever their sexual practices, they engage in them in the safest way possible. The Guide provides this information.

Explaining the risks associated with anal sex to people who choose to engage in this behaviour was the purpose of the anal sex article. The article is not intended to advocate anal sex. It should be noted that the anal sex article is only one of 19 articles and feature items contained in the Guide.
(4) The Department took into account the Cleo readership which is as follows:
These figures were provided by Cleo, and were sourced from Morgan—October 1992—September 1993. There was no further break-down available to determine the proportion of teenagers.
(5) The Department considered that young women who regularly read Cleo magazine, and other such magazines, would have been exposed to information regarding relationships and sexual activities.

It is essential therefore that these young people be presented with information that enables them to protect themselves from HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases if they choose to become sexually active.

(6) The Department provided $200,000 to Australian Consolidated Press to produce the Safe Sex Guide, which was banded to the December 1994 issue of Cleo Magazine. The Department received a further 50,000 copies of the Safe Sex Guide. A further $50,000 was allocated for the project development, launch and related administrative costs.
The use of such a popular women's magazine provides a unique opportunity to communicate with young women about important sexual health issues such as sexually transmitted diseases.

The project is consistent with the National HIV/AIDS Strategy which identifies women as a target group for education and prevention programs; and aims to eliminate the transmission of HIV and minimise the personal and social impact of HIV infection.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 9 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Government ensure that (a) Higher Education Contribution Scheme liability payments will not be increased, (b) an up-front fee system will not be introduced and (c) tertiary funding per student in Western Australia will not decrease in the 1995-96 Budget.
(2) Will he consider introducing a rebate for students receiving low incomes to assist them to purchase necessary textbooks.
(3) Has he investigated the cost to students of textbooks; if not, will he or his Department (a) investigate the matter or (b) ask the Prices Surveillance Authority to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government has not increased the size of an individual's Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) debt in the 1995-96 Budget or introduced up-front fees for Australian undergraduate students. The Government has increased its commitment to the further development of a high quality and accessible Australian higher education system. The 1995-96 Budget provides $16.5 billion over the 1996-98 funding triennium for the higher education sector, including funding for additional student places in areas of growing population and growth in research and research infrastructure.

In 1995 the average funding rate per EFTSU in Western Australia is $9,995 (at the 1995-96 Budget price level). This includes both undergraduate and postgraduate students but excludes funding for capital projects. The rate will increase in 1996 and 1997, with the average funding per EFTSU in 1997 reaching $10,070 (at 1995-96 Budget prices).

In the 1995-96 Budget, Western Australia was allocated 400 growth places in 1997 and 350 growth places in 1998. These places are all for undergraduates and have been funded at a rate of $9,300 (at the 1995-96 Budget price level).

(2) The Government already provides financial assistance for disadvantaged students through the AUSTUDY scheme to assist them with the costs of their education. In addition, AUSTUDY recipients may apply for the AUSTUDY Supplement, an optional loan scheme which offers tertiary students the opportunity to increase the amount of money they can get while studying. In 1995, AUSTUDY will assist around half a million students at a cost of $1.5 billion. It is a matter for students how they spend their AUSTUDY allowance. The Government will not be introducing a separate rebate for the purchase of textbooks.
In addition, students have access to university libraries, which are funded by the Commonwealth Government, and may make use of these facilities rather than buy textbooks.

(3) In late April 1995, the Prices Surveillance Authority submitted its report to the Government on its Inquiry into Book Prices and Parallel Imports. I understand the report included a limited study of text book prices. The Government will be considering the PSA's report.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Dasfleet and Transport Workers' Union: Sales Tax Negotiations

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 1 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Have negotiations taken place between Dasfleet and the Transport Workers' Union over payment of sales tax relating to a 1992 lease; if so, (a) have the negotiations been completed and (b) will he provide details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Yes.

(b) In December 1992 Dasfleet entered into a leasing agreement with the Transport Workers Union in respect of 62 vehicles. There was no fixed term for the agreement, however the vehicles are leased on a one year/40,000km basis.
The aspect of this agreement that rightly created public controversy was the fixing of a rent based on the assumption that the TWU held sales and fuel excise tax exempt status.

In December of 1993 following a Dasfleet review of its contracts the Australian Tax Office confirmed that with the possible exception of a small number of vehicles used pursuant to tax exempt community service schemes, unions were not exempt from sales or fuel tax. Certainly none of the 62 vehicles had such exemption.
From January 1994 Dasfleet insisted that rentals be increased to a full tax inclusive rate. The monthly increase varied from $200 for a Magna to $260 for a Ford Fairmont.

It needs to be understood that Dasfleet as part of the Crown is not liable to pay sales tax or excise duty. It pays notional duty only to honour its commitment to maintain a level playing field with private sector competitors. In this context Dasfleet paid $234,683 into consolidated revenue.
The Attorney General's Department advised Dasfleet that it could not maintain an action in debt against the TWU in respect of lost notional sales tax or excise duty.
The legal principle here, simply put, is that it is not possible to sue for debts paid on somebody else's behalf if there is no legal obligation to make such a payment in the first place.

It has been suggested in some quarters that the TWU should be paying penalty tax or interest. Those suggestions misunderstand the legal position. The TWU was never liable to pay the tax and penalties do not enter the picture. There being no debt, interest could not possibly accrue.
All we have is a situation where the rent fixed under agreement was insufficient because acting on the Union's representations Dasfleet failed to take tax into consideration.

It was for these reasons that I asked Dasfleet to seek Senior Counsel's advice as to whether it might be possible to maintain an action against the TWU for damages for misleading or deceptive conduct under Section 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr. P. Donohoe QC duly advised as follows:

PARA.TAB: Firstly, if such an action was successful the damages would be limited to the value of the lost opportunity to enter into a contract incorporating higher tax rates.

Secondly, because the TWU had been paying the higher sales tax inclusive rates since January 1994 the amount of those damages would only relate to the lost opportunity in the year to December 1993 and would be less than the notional tax paid.

Thirdly, there were a number of complex legal reasons in respect of which Dasfleet's suit might fail. (The union's defence was that it had made an innocent mistake about its liability for sales and fuel tax and that Section 52 did not apply) and
Fourthly, litigation was not the appropriate course and the issue should be resolved under the dispute resolution clause in the lease agreement.
I accepted Senior Counsel's advice and agreed to Dasfleet proceeding accordingly.

The outcome of the dispute resolution process was an agreement by the TWU to pay to Dasfleet $144,263.38 which represents full repayment of outstanding fuel excise and a proportion of the sales tax liability that in the opinion of Dasfleet's legal advisers could reasonably have been expected by way of damages for the year when no tax was included in the rent.
My advice is that following the sale of the vehicles Dasfleet has now made a modest profit on

ANSWER.PARA: this transaction and in the circumstances the settlement represents a satisfactory resolution of the matter.

PARA.TAB: I take the view that the Commonwealth as the administrator of sales tax law was in the best position to know and verify questions of tax exempt status and should not have relied on the advice of its clients in such matters.
I also take the view that Dasfleet contracts should be for fixed terms.
Dasfleet instituted procedures late in 1993 to prevent a repetition of their mistake in 1992.
